Digital Trends Home > Virtual Reality > The battle of the entry-level headsets:â€¦ The battle of the entry-level headsets: Googleâ€™s Daydream View vs. Samsungâ€™s Gear VR By Will Nicol â€” Updated May 13, 2017 6:01 am Share Samsung Don't Fall Behind Stay current with a recap of today's Tech News from DigitalÂ Trends Get today's popular DigitalÂ Trends articles in your inbox: For as much as tech writers talk about the VR revolution, virtual reality still remains purely theoreticalÂ for most consumers. Headsets such asÂ the HTC Vive and Oculus Rift are expensive, as areÂ the high-end computers required to run them. There are plenty ofÂ entry-level VR headsets that run off of smartphones, but many are too weak to deliverÂ a truly engaging experience. Of the smartphone-powered VR headsets on the market, only Googleâ€™s Daydream View, a headset designed to be used in conjunction with Daydream VR, and Samsungâ€™s Gear VR, a VR accessory compatible with Samsungâ€™s Galaxy phones, have impressed us so far. But how do the two compare? Here, we take an in-depth look at both to find out. Daydream View Gear VR Optical Lens 90-degree field of view 101-degree field of view Display Depends on device 2560 x 1440 pixel Super AMOLED Refresh Rate Depends on device 60 Hz Required Hardware Google Pixel, Pixel XL,Â Huawei Mate 9 Pro, ZTE Axon 7, Motorola Moto Z, Asus Zenfone 3 Deluxe Galaxy Note 5, Note 7, Galaxy S6, S6 Edge, S6 Edge+, S7, S7 Edge, S8, S8+ Sensor Accelerator, gyrometer, proximity Accelerator, gyrometer, proximity Focal Adjustment N/A Focus adjustment wheel Interpupillary Distance Coverage ~64 mm 54~70 mm Physical UI Motion controller (included) Touchpad, Back button, volume key, and Gear VR controller (included) Connection Wireless connection USB Type-C and MicroUSB Dimensions 166.8 x 4.18 x 3.88 mm 201.9 x 116.4 x 92.6 mm Weight 220 grams 310 grams Color variants Slate, snow, and crimson Blue black, orchard gray Price $79, plus cost of phone $130, plus cost of phone Availability Available now Available now DT Review 3.5 out of 5 stars 4 out of 5 starsÂ (late-2015 model) Design Google designed the Daydream View to be comfortable, first and foremost. Most VR headsets are very obviously gadgets, made of a lot of plastic and rubber. ButÂ thatâ€™s not the case here â€” Google partneredÂ with a clothing brand to achieve the headsetâ€™s look and feel. The plastic frame feels a little cheap, but weâ€™re big fans of the Daydream Viewâ€™s soft-touch fabric. Itâ€™s lightweight and cushion-y, and has somewhat of a â€œcomfy sweatpants vibe.â€ It doesnâ€™t feel fragile, and the the face mask can be removed and washed â€” a feature we came to appreciate in our review, after watching hours of VR content. The Gear VR, on the other hand, is made of plastic with a matte finish, and itâ€™s lined with a rubber face mask. The newest generation of the device has slightly larger lenses with a separator between them, and an improved smartphone cover that snaps more easily onto the front of the device. Googleâ€™s goal with the View is ease of use. As such, the View has no wires to fiddle with. YouÂ simply unfasten the elastic strap at the top of the headset to open the front panel, slide your phone between the front panel and lens, close it up, and refasten the strap. You donâ€™t need to press anything toÂ launch Daydream â€” the NFC chip in your phone will do that for you. With the Gear VR, you need to plug in your phone via the micro-USB or USB Type-C connection. Controls When it comes to controls, the Gear VR and View are fairly comparable. Googleâ€™s headset comes with a two-button controller outfitted with motion sensors, a trackpad, and a volume rocker on the side. The large circular dimple at the top acts as a selection button, and the lowest button serves as the Home button. The device resembles a Wii remote, andÂ packs a 220mAh rechargeable battery that lasts anywhere between 30 minutes and an hour. When drained, it charges viaÂ USB Type-C. In our review of the Daydream View, we were impressed by its responsiveness â€” there isnâ€™t a lot of latency. And we liked that it could be paired with up to two phones, which comes in handy if youâ€™re sharing a Daydream View with another person. Samsungâ€™s newest Gear VR headset, on the other hand, comes with the Gear VR Controller, an Oculus-designed motion wand that looks like a miniature HTC Vive controller. It, like the Daydream View controller, has a touch-sensitive trackpad that doubles as a clickable selection button. Below the trackpad are Home, Select, Volume, and Back buttons, and on the underside is a trigger. A wrist strap is also located near the bottom, which helps prevent you from losing your grip. Unlike the Daydream View remote, the Gear VR ControllerÂ takes a pair of AA batteries, which Samsung says last up to 40 days. This, however, is entirely dependent on the battery manufacturer and how much you use it. Inside is a gyroscope, accelerometer, and magnometer for tracking motion, allowing you to point, drag, drop, tilt, shoot, and carry out a host of other actions. In our brief time with the Gear VR ControllerÂ at Mobile World Congress, it felt sturdy, stable, and easy to grasp. The Home and Volume buttons were responsive, and the trigger felt satisfying and springy. The Gear VR also has a built-inÂ directional pad and Back button, and can be paired with third-party controllers. Most importantly, bothÂ headsets have been designed to accommodate users with glasses. Performance The Daydream Viewâ€™s performance depends heavily on which phone youâ€™re using to power it. According to Googleâ€™s official Daydream specifications, any phone with at least a 1080p display between 4.7 and 6 inches in size qualifies. It must support a refresh rate of at least 60 Hz, however, and a â€œlow-persistenceâ€ mode. It also must have at least two physical processor cores, one of which must be assigned exclusively to the Daydream app. The list of Daydream-supported smartphones is growing by the day, but here are some of the most popular models: The Moto ZÂ and Moto Z Force, both of which have screen resolutions of 2,560 x 1,440, Qualcommâ€™s Snapdragon 820 processor, and 4GB of RAM. They start at $624 and $720, respectively. The ZTE Axon 7, which has a screen resolution of 2,560 x 1,440 pixels, a Snapdragon 820 processor, and either 4GB or 6GB of RAM. It starts at $400. The Asus Zenfone 3 Deluxe, which has a screen resolution of 2,560 x 1,440 pixels, a Snapdragon 821 processor, and 6GB of RAM. Pricing has yet to be announced. The Google Pixel and Pixel XLÂ which have screen resolutions of 1080p and 1440p respectively, a Snapdragon 821 processor, and 4GB of RAM. TheÂ Pixel starts at $650 and the XL at $770. The Gear VR, on the other hand, requires a Samsung Galaxy phone such as the Galaxy S8, S7, or the S7 Edge. These have 1440p displays. Daydream-compatible smartphones and Samsungâ€™s Galaxy phones may pack different components, but Samsung and Google have done their best to establish baseline specsÂ â€” even on â€œlow-endâ€ hardware, youâ€™ll have a pretty good VR experience using both Daydream and the Gear VR. For now, it doesnâ€™t seem like either headset will make for a remarkably different VR experience. Software Googleâ€™s approach to software on the Daydream View is commendable. Itâ€™s simple, intuitive, and beginner-friendly â€” thereâ€™s even an interactive guide that teaches you how to use the remote, and a tutorial that has you exploring the woods with a flashlight. The Daydream home screen resembles the layout of apps on the Oculus Rift. You can view your most recently-used apps, along with aÂ library of all installed Daydream apps. Apps also download from Google Play, which means you donâ€™t have to take off the headset to download an app or game. But you can browse the Daydream app whenÂ youâ€™re not in VR mode, too, and quickly launch apps that way. In our review of the Gear VR, we noted that the software interface had â€œa blocky, flat design,â€ but that navigating it was fairly easy. It doesnâ€™t offer the same cute, intuitive onboarding experience as the Daydream View, but itâ€™s fairly self-explanatory.Â On the left and right sides are the Library and Oculus Store, where you can download various apps and games. You scroll through pages using the Gear VRâ€™s built-in trackpad, or the Gear VR Controller. The Gear VR boasts hundreds of VR experiences and games. Some of the highlights include Facebook 360, a hub for the social networkâ€™s 360-degree video and picture content, andÂ Minecraft, Microsoftâ€™s Lego-like creation platform. Other standouts includeÂ Hitman Go: VR Edition, an adaptation of the smartphone-centricÂ Hitman Go,Â andÂ Paint VR,Â aÂ blank VR canvas on which you can doodle. Earlier this year, Oculus also announced that more than 70 in-development titles would soon take advantage of the Gear VR Controller. Googleâ€™s Daydream platform may not be able to match the Gear VR when it comes to volume, but that doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s without compelling content of its own.Â A few highlights include Googleâ€™s suite of VR-optimized apps â€” YouTube VR, Street View, Google Play Movies, etc. â€” as well as experiences such asÂ Wonderglade, Mekorama VR,Â Hunters Gate, andÂ Star Chart VR. You can also use the headset to access coverageÂ from TheÂ Wall Street Journal VR, CNN VR, The Guardian VR, and The New York Times, along with video apps such as HBO Go, Netflix, and Hulu VR. Recent titles likeÂ Gunjack 2: End of ShiftÂ andÂ Danger GoatÂ are just an added plus. Pricing and availability Both of these headsets are affordable gateways into VR. Either iteration of theÂ Gear VR will run you a cool $130, andÂ comes bundled with the aforementioned Gear VR Controller. The Daydream View currently retails for $79, and is available in snow, slate, or crimson configurations. Conclusion Last year, OculusÂ had a virtual monopoly on entry-level VR. The Daydream View is the Gear VRâ€™s first major competitor, and itâ€™s a neck-and-neck race. Weâ€™re big fans of the Daydream Viewâ€™s softer, more comfortable headset and easy-to-use software. But Samsungâ€™s new Gear VR Controller shakes things up. It offers more inputs and longer battery life than the Daydream Viewâ€™s controller, and supports exclusive games and experiences. Our review of the Gear VR Controller is forthcoming, so weâ€™ll have to call it a tie for now. But in the meantime, itâ€™s tough to go wrong with either platform. Netflix confirms it is blocking rooted/unlocked devices, app itself is still working (for now) Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/05/13 3:08pm PDTMay 13, 2017 127 Plus 1 on G+ 452 Share on Facebook 161 Share on Twitter Total Shares740 Applications News Earlier today, Netflix started showing up as 'incompatible' on the Play Store for rooted and unlocked Android devices. However, the app itself continued to work fine, leading some (including myself) to think it could have been an accident. However, Netflix has now confirmed to us that blocking modified devices from downloading the app was intentional. This is the full statement: With our latest 5.0 release, we now fully rely on the Widevine DRM provided by Google; therefore, many devices that are not Google-certified or have been altered will no longer work with our latest app and those users will no longer see the Netflix app in the Play Store. If you're not familiar with it, Widevine is a Google-made DRM technology that works across various desktop and mobile platforms. Widevine categorizes devices into three security levels, ranging from all processes running in the Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) to not running anything in TEE at all. However,Â the Play Store listing seems tied to a device's SaftetyNet status (which is used by Android Pay), rather than the Widevine TEE. For example, Artem's bootloader-unlocked stock Pixel is still on Widevine Level 1, the most secure level, but fails SafetyNet because it is unlocked. The update's changelog also confirms the: "Version 5.0 only works with devices that are certified by Google and meet all Android requirements." What isn't exactly clear is why only the Play store listing is blocked, but the app itself continued to function normally. I tried both Netflix 4.16 and 5.0.4 (the latest version, from today), and both worked without problems on my unlocked and rooted Galaxy Tab S (which is labeled as Widevine Security Level 3). Maybe at some point the app will stop working, but that does not appear to be the case right now. If you have a blocked device, I recommend following the Pushbullet channel for Netflix on APKMirror (click the Pushbullet button on that page) so you can continue to receive updates outside the Play Store. Tags block DRM netflix widevine subscribe ... Previous Story [Deal Alert] Benson-approved 9ft USB-C AmazonBasics cables are $7.99 (20% off), 6ft 15% off ... Netflix confirms it is blocking rooted/unlocked devices, app itself is still working (for now) Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/05/13 3:08pm PDTMay 13, 2017 127 Plus 1 on G+ 452 Share on Facebook 161 Share on Twitter Total Shares740 Applications News Earlier today, Netflix started showing up as 'incompatible' on the Play Store for rooted and unlocked Android devices. However, the app itself continued to work fine, leading some (including myself) to think it could have been an accident. However, Netflix has now confirmed to us that blocking modified devices from downloading the app was intentional. This is the full statement: With our latest 5.0 release, we now fully rely on the Widevine DRM provided by Google; therefore, many devices that are not Google-certified or have been altered will no longer work with our latest app and those users will no longer see the Netflix app in the Play Store. If you're not familiar with it, Widevine is a Google-made DRM technology that works across various desktop and mobile platforms. Widevine categorizes devices into three security levels, ranging from all processes running in the Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) to not running anything in TEE at all. However,Â the Play Store listing seems tied to a device's SaftetyNet status (which is used by Android Pay), rather than the Widevine TEE. For example, Artem's bootloader-unlocked stock Pixel is still on Widevine Level 1, the most secure level, but fails SafetyNet because it is unlocked. The update's changelog also confirms the: "Version 5.0 only works with devices that are certified by Google and meet all Android requirements." What isn't exactly clear is why only the Play store listing is blocked, but the app itself continued to function normally. I tried both Netflix 4.16 and 5.0.4 (the latest version, from today), and both worked without problems on my unlocked and rooted Galaxy Tab S (which is labeled as Widevine Security Level 3). Maybe at some point the app will stop working, but that does not appear to be the case right now. If you have a blocked device, I recommend following the Pushbullet channel for Netflix on APKMirror (click the Pushbullet button on that page) so you can continue to receive updates outside the Play Store. Tags block DRM netflix widevine subscribe ... Previous Story [Deal Alert] Benson-approved 9ft USB-C AmazonBasics cables are $7.99 (20% off), 6ft 15% off ... NDTV Business Hindi Movies Cricket Good Times Food Tech Auto Apps Prime Art Weddings Sections Home | Offbeat COMMENTS Sections Live TV Videos Latest India Opinion Cities World IPL Photos Schedule Trends OffBeat People Health IndiansÂ Abroad South CheatÂ Sheet Voices Forums Weather News Alerts Mother's Day 2017: Google Wishes All The Super Mums With A Special Doodle Google celebrated Mother's day 2017 with a special doodle. Offbeat | Edited by Nonika Marwaha | Updated: May 14, 2017 11:34 IST 230 Shares EMAIL PRINT COMMENTS Mothers Day 2017: Google dedicates a special doodle to all the mums. New Delhi:Â  Google today is celebrating Mother's day 2017 by dedicating a special doodle to all the mothers. Mother's Day is celebrated every year on the second Sunday of May. It is the day specially dedicated to the woman who devotes all her life for the well-being of her child and in return for this selfless love from her, she expects nothing. Google represents the celebration of 'motherhood' through its animated doodle and has honoured all the sacrifices' a mother makes for her child. The Google Doodle is a series of story of a pregnant cactus and her journey as a mother from giving birth to her baby cacti, to taking care of it and finally living a settled life with the grown up babies. The six different gif images show the various stages every mother has gone through during her motherhood. The first image shows a pregnancy cactus waiting to give birth and eager to take on the responsibility. The second gif image shows the process of watering the plant which represents mothers breastfeeding their kids. The third, fourth and fifth gifs show the journey of the child (the cacti) growing up under the mother's love and guidance and finally ends with a happy cacti family held together by the main character of the house, the mother. Though there is no doubt about it that every day can be celebrated as mother's day. But this day is an important occasion that gives us an opportunity to thank for all that she has done for us and to make her feel special and loved. As we grow up, we tend to become so busy and occupied with our fast growing life that we often forget her and give less time to her. We forget that she is the reason behind our growth and success. From learning how to speak till our first job interview, from learning how to walk till driving a car, from having first crush till first heartbreak she has always been with us in some or the other way. She is indeed a blessing and the best gift given to us by god. No matter what we do for her, nothing can match her selfless love and care. So, go and tell your mother what she means to you and Happy Mother's Day to all the super moms in the world! Netflix confirms it is blocking rooted/unlocked devices, app itself is still working (for now) Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/05/13 3:08pm PDTMay 13, 2017 127 Plus 1 on G+ 452 Share on Facebook 161 Share on Twitter Total Shares740 Applications News Earlier today, Netflix started showing up as 'incompatible' on the Play Store for rooted and unlocked Android devices. However, the app itself continued to work fine, leading some (including myself) to think it could have been an accident. However, Netflix has now confirmed to us that blocking modified devices from downloading the app was intentional. This is the full statement: With our latest 5.0 release, we now fully rely on the Widevine DRM provided by Google; therefore, many devices that are not Google-certified or have been altered will no longer work with our latest app and those users will no longer see the Netflix app in the Play Store. If you're not familiar with it, Widevine is a Google-made DRM technology that works across various desktop and mobile platforms. Widevine categorizes devices into three security levels, ranging from all processes running in the Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) to not running anything in TEE at all. However,Â the Play Store listing seems tied to a device's SaftetyNet status (which is used by Android Pay), rather than the Widevine TEE. For example, Artem's bootloader-unlocked stock Pixel is still on Widevine Level 1, the most secure level, but fails SafetyNet because it is unlocked. The update's changelog also confirms the: "Version 5.0 only works with devices that are certified by Google and meet all Android requirements." What isn't exactly clear is why only the Play store listing is blocked, but the app itself continued to function normally. I tried both Netflix 4.16 and 5.0.4 (the latest version, from today), and both worked without problems on my unlocked and rooted Galaxy Tab S (which is labeled as Widevine Security Level 3). Maybe at some point the app will stop working, but that does not appear to be the case right now. If you have a blocked device, I recommend following the Pushbullet channel for Netflix on APKMirror (click the Pushbullet button on that page) so you can continue to receive updates outside the Play Store. Tags block DRM netflix widevine subscribe ... Previous Story [Deal Alert] Benson-approved 9ft USB-C AmazonBasics cables are $7.99 (20% off), 6ft 15% off ... First the vpn's now this... why oh why??? Jimk4003 Surely because licensing is regionally specific, and because rooting has the potential to defeat DRM. I get that it might be annoying for some people, but aren't the reasons obvious? David Juarez But root?? Lol Semianonymous Probably an effort to reduce Region spoofing? Idk how easy that is to do on a stock device. Jimk4003 Because rooting has the potential to defeat DRM. mjh49783ab DRM doesn't work. All DRM does is inconvenience the end user. Jimk4003 Possibly. But Netflix have to negotiate licencing deals with the movie studios, and having DRM helps reassure the studios that the movies they have spent millions of dollars making aren't going to get stolen off Netflix without any attempt to stop it. mjh49783ab One could make the argument that rooting the phone may compromise the DRM. But blocking users from unlocking their phones to switch carriers? That is total bullshit, and is just the sort of thing that encourages users to pirate the content. Most people won't care, or even notice the change. h4rr4r It does not matter, if it drives even one person to piracy that is a loss. Jimk4003 But if they can ensure better licensing deals via these new terms, which will attract more customers at the expense of a few rooted users who make up a tiny fraction of overall users; will Netflix care about that loss? h4rr4r But if it encourages piracy the other side of the contract should want to avoid it. Entertainment Yo Ho, Pirates Of The Caribbean Fans, It's Paul McCartney As A Pirate Dunkirk-Style Trailer For 'Battle Of The Bastards' Proves How Damn Cinematic Game Of Thrones Is Alden Ehrenreich's Han Solo Hair Is So On Point UnReal Estate Brings Popular Culture Locations To Life ThroughÂ Art Toggle navigation Reviews Camera Reviews Car Reviews Phone Reviews PC Reviews Smartwatch Reviews Gadgets Reviews Gaming Reviews Entertainment Reviews Smart Home & Gadgets Mobile Car Tech Online Science & Health Cameras Computing Gaming Entertainment Deals: Protect Your Privacy Anywhere In The World With This VPN Riese & Mueller Charger GT E-Bike: Australian Review Deals: Grow Your Programming Skills With This Massive Course Bundle SBS On Demand Is Now On Chromecast For iOS Microsoft's Apps Problem Has Never Been More Dire Alex Cranz May 14, 2017, 9:00am â‹… Filed to:Â  build computing microsoft microsoft build 2017 windows windows 10 windows 10 s windows store Share At Microsoft's Build conference, the dorkiest of companies put on a big show, complete with fog machines and fancy lights, in order to show it's a cool competitor to Apple and Google. The speakers who came on stage during keynotes had stylish hair. "Do they have dressers backstage?" an attendee asked a group of us when it was all over. Images: Alex Cranz/Gizmodo Build exists to get developers excited. The biggest devs blow upwards of $US2000 ($2709) for a three-day pass to the event, where they have unlimited drinks, plentiful meals and access to Microsoft's best and brightest. Part of Microsoft's wooing process involves appearing "hip" to a group of developers who resemble the cast of Silicon Valley in all the worst ways. Hence the light show and Microsoft EVP Terry Myerson's questionable hoodie and leather vest combo. It wants these devs so amped that they will rush back to their MacBook Airs and Surface Books to crank out brilliant software, hopefully for Microsoft's Windows Store, which has just one third of the apps of much cooler stores from Google and Apple. With the arrival of Windows 10 S, which can only use apps from the Windows Store, the app marketplace has never been more important than today. Yet time after time over the course of the event, Microsoft dropped the ball on its pitch to developers in favour of niche distractions. Apple's a monolith of money and users, and thanks to Android and Chrome OS, Google is right there with it. Both have OS platforms with heavily used app stores. They have built customer bases of hungry fans that enthusiastically embrace their hardware and software products, and consequently, developers want to build apps that work with Apple and Google platforms. Microsoft, on the other hand, can't seem to ditch the buttoned-up association it's developed for making the work computer you don't want to use. Its reputation is seemingly forever cemented by those old Mac vs PC commercials. Attempts to rewrite the script have been met with mixed success. On the hardware side, Microsoft has become a genuine player in the field of coveted kit. The Surface Pro and Studio are ambitious devices that are legitimately exciting. The Surface Laptop announced earlier this month is one of the most interesting products announced so far this year. But Microsoft's software landscape is still dorktown and one of the big ways Microsoft's attempting to undorkify things is by leaning into the Windows Store. There's a problem though. Microsoft's app store in uncommonly small compared to the other guys. According to Microsoft, in 2015 there were just 669,000 apps available. (The company hasn't officially updated that number since.) According to Statista Apple and Google both have more than three times that number of apps available in their stores. The number of available apps alone doesn't necessarily dictate the quality of someone's computing experience, but it remains a common metric for success, and if Microsoft wants to look cooler in the software space, it needs a big awesome app store full of big awesome apps. Microsoft stunned the audience of Build when it announced iTunes was coming to the store just a week after announcing Spotify's arrival. Those are two hugely important apps, and you could feel the energy in the keynote after the announcement. Developers and press looked at one another, baffled and delighted. An Apple app would appear in the Windows Store! Then Microsoft immediately squandered that excitement. The rest of the focus both on stage and later in the "Hub," the primary showroom for the conference, wasn't on the cool apps traditional users might want, but on the deeply nerdy niche stuff. During the keynote itself, Microsoft glossed over the lifestyle apps to focus on Autodesk and Linux. Autodesk was up on stage to announce that Autodesk Stingray was headed to the store. Stingray is an engine used to build things in 3D and is almost exclusively used by 3D artists and engineers. After that announcement, Microsoft followed up with the news that Linux was coming to the store. If you're excited about the Linux distributions Ubuntu, Suse and Fedora arriving to the Windows Store, know you're uncommon. It's big news for developers, but meaningless to people who would normally seek out apps on an app store in the first place. Site of the Build keynote. There are lots of blue lights and...fog? Given Microsoft's enthusiasm for the store, it was weird that the company's newly announced operating system, Windows 10 S, which can only get apps through the store, was mostly absent from the conference, apart from a few mentions during the keynote. You couldn't find it anywhere on the show floor, where developers mingle with Microsoft personnel. Nerd city. The Store booth had a lone TV screen with a rep standing in front of it â€” and that rep had not been briefed on Windows 10 S. In fact, it seemed no one had. Every Microsoft rep I asked seemed bewildered by Windows 10 S questions. They could say it was "exciting" but they had no spiel ready for why it was exciting, nor why the Store was crucial to its success. And no one could explain what, fundamentally, might have changed about the Windows Store to make it an appealing avenue for app launches after a five years of sluggish adoption. Even app developers that were bullish about the platform were frustratingly vague about what was different now compared to when the Store launched in 2012, and why Windows 10 S would not go the way of its failed store-focused predecessors Windows RT and Windows 8.1 with Bing. Christoph Teschner and Michael Simmons were positively giddy about Windows 10 S when I sat down with them in a high-rise hotel near the conference. Both men are employees of Algoriddim, and were in Seattle because their app, DJay Pro, had just received the App Creator of the Year award. "I think that's the future," Simmons said of the Windows App store. Teschner pointed to his own youth, growing up with Apple's app stores for Mac and iOS and how it had prepared him for the Windows Store. "People are used to app stores now," he said. "It felt sort of natural to me when I first got my Windows Store." Though they were reluctant to give exact numbers or concrete evidence of a successful Windows Store launch, Simmons said "Windows fulfilled our expectations." He praised the development process in particular. "Seeing developer tools ten years ago, it's a total leap today. It's an evolution and we're in the middle of it." Neither man could give a concrete reason for why they felt Windows 10 S had a chance to succeed when its predecessors failed so badly, but sitting in a room and soaking up their optimism it was hard not to be swayed a little. And it's that kind of optimism for app developers that Microsoft will need if it hopes to actually fill the Store with cool apps. If those men had been on the show floor, showing off their app and talking up their own experiences with developing for the store, Build might have actually projected the image Microsoft desperately needs. But Microsoft is still figuring it out. It has ditched the pocket protector, but it's still not cool. WATCH MORE: Tech News Comments soldant @soldant May 14, 2017, 11:48am Honestly I think MS allowing you to upgrade out of Windows 10 S for free is an admission that it isn't going to do well. Almost nobody wants Windows Store apps - most of them are served by better quality desktop apps or by a browser tab. The Windows Store can't seem to make up its mind whether it wants to be an answer to iOS/Android apps (and that market clearly has no room for a third competitor) or a replacement for desktop apps (where it routinely fails). Basically, it's just an alternative to options that frankly work better. The cynic in me sees it as an MS attempt at ultimately pushing towards a closed platform in the consumer market - but that didn't work for Apple with MacOS and it's got no hope in hell of working here. Reply 2 lee978 @978lee May 14, 2017, 4:40pm Microsoft are looking enviously at Apple & Android App Stores. The control this gives them, as well as the data and the revenue is serving them well. However much of Microsoft appeal is the fact you don't have to use their App store. The privacy this gives users, the flexibility, user control and potential cost savings is part of Windows appeal. Take this away and they will lose customers. Reply 0 Join the discussion! Log In Sign Up Guest Access Join the discussion! Cancel Reply Log In / Sign Up Name Email You are starting a new discussion. Search the print archives This copy is for your personal non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies of Toronto Star content for distribution to colleagues, clients or customers, or inquire about permissions/licensing, please go to: www.TorontoStarReprints.com News World How Google took over U.S. classrooms Tech giant has outmanoeuvred Apple and Microsoft with powerful combination of low-cost laptops and free apps. A student uses a Google-powered laptop next to a paper-laden binder, in class at Brooklyn College Academy in New York. Google is transforming public education in the U.S. with low-cost laptops and free apps, in turn helping to drive a philosophical change â€” prioritizing skills such as teamwork and problem-solving while de-emphasizing the teaching of traditional academic knowledge, such as math formulas.Â Â (SASHA MASLOV / THE NEW YORK TIMES)Â Â  By NATASHA SINGERThe New York Times Sat., May 13, 2017 CHICAGOâ€”The sixth-graders at Newton Bateman, a public elementary school here, know the Google drill. In a social-science class last year, the students each grabbed a Google-powered laptop. They opened Google Classroom, an app where teachers make assignments. Then they clicked on Google Docs, a writing program, and began composing essays. Chicago Public Schools, the third-largest school district in the United States, with about 381,000 students, is at the forefront of a profound shift in U.S. education: the Googlification of the classroom. In five years, Google has helped upend the sales methods companies use to place their products in classrooms. It has enlisted teachers and administrators to promote Googleâ€™s products to other schools. It has directly reached out to educators to test its products â€” effectively bypassing senior district officials. And it has outmanoeuvred Apple and Microsoft with a powerful combination of low-cost laptops, called Chromebooks, and free classroom apps. Today, more than half of primary- and secondary-school students in the U.S. â€” more than 30 million children â€” use Google education apps such as Gmail and Docs, the company said. And Chromebooks, Google-powered laptops that initially struggled to find a purpose, now account for more than half the mobile devices shipped to U.S. schools. Article Continued Below â€œBetween the fall of 2012 and now, Google went from an interesting possibility to the dominant way that schools around the countryâ€ teach students to find information, create documents and turn them in, said Hal Friedlander, former chief information officer for the New York City Department of Education. In doing so, Google is helping to drive a philosophical change in public education â€” prioritizing training children in skills such as teamwork and problem-solving while de-emphasizing the teaching of traditional academic knowledge, such as math formulas. It puts Google, and the tech economy, at the centre of one of the great debates that has raged in U.S. education for more than a century: whether the purpose of public schools is to turn out knowledgeable citizens or skilled workers. Schools may be giving Google more than they are getting: generations of future customers. Google makes $30 per device by selling management services for the millions of Chromebooks that ship to schools. But by habituating students to its offerings at a young age, Google obtains something much more valuable. Every year, several million American students graduate from high school. And not only does Google make it easy for those who have school Google accounts to upload their trove of school Gmail, Docs and other files to regular Google consumer accounts â€” but schools encourage them to do so. Some parents warn that Google could profit by using personal details from their childrenâ€™s school email to build more powerful marketing profiles of them as young adults. Jonathan Rochelle, director of Googleâ€™s education apps group, said that when students transfer their school emails and files to a personal Google account, that account is governed by Googleâ€™s privacy policy. â€œPersonal Gmail accounts may serve ads,â€ he said, but files in Google Drive are â€œnever scanned for the purpose of showing ads.â€ In 2013, Rochelle, a co-developer of Google Docs, set up a team at Google to create apps specifically for schools. To spread those tools, Jaime Casap, Googleâ€™s global education evangelist, began travelling around the U.S. with a motivational message: Rather than tout specific Google products, Casap told educators that they could improve their studentsâ€™ college and career prospects by creatively using online tools. But that also caused problems in Chicago and another district when Google went looking for teachers to try a new app â€” effectively bypassing district administrators. In both cases, Google found itself reined in. Google derives most of its revenue from online advertising â€” much of it targeted through sophisticated use of peopleâ€™s data. Google declined to provide a breakdown of the exact details the company collects from student use of its services. Bram Bout, director of Googleâ€™s education unit, pointed to a Google privacy notice listing the categories of information that the companyâ€™s education services collect, such as location data and â€œdetails of how a user used our service.â€ Bout said that student data in Googleâ€™s core education services (including Gmail, Calendar and Docs) â€œis only used to provide the services themselves, so students can do things like communicate using email.â€ These services do not show ads, he said, and â€œdo not use personal data resulting from use of these services to target ads.â€ *** In 2006, Casap persuaded Arizona State University officials to scrap their costly internal email service and replace it with a free version of the Gmail-and-Docs package that Google had been selling to companies. In one semester, the vast majority of the universityâ€™s approximately 65,000 students signed up. Northwestern University, the University of Southern California and many others followed. This became Googleâ€™s education marketing playbook: Woo school officials with easy-to-use, money-saving services. Then enlist schools to market to other schools. Casap decided to try the strategy with public schools. As it happened, officials at the Oregon Department of Education were looking to help local schools cut their email costs, said Steve Nelson, a former department official. In 2010, the state officially made Googleâ€™s education apps available to its school districts. Google then developed a growth strategy aimed at teachers, who could influence the administrators who make technology decisions. *** At Chicago Public Schools, the teacher-centric strategy played out almost perfectly. In 2012, Jennie Magiera, then a fourth-grade teacher in Chicago, wanted her students to use Google Docs. Because the district wasnâ€™t yet using Googleâ€™s apps, she said, she independently set up six consumer accounts for her class. Chicago Public Schools was looking to trim the $2 million a year it was spending on Microsoft Exchange and another email service. In March 2012, the district chose Google. In interviews, Chicago administrators said they asked Google to sign a contract agreeing, among other things, to comply with the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act. That law permits federally funded educational institutions to share studentsâ€™ personally identifiable information with certain school vendors, provided those companies use that information only for school purposes. Instead, Google initially proposed abiding by its own company policies, said Edward Wagner, the districtâ€™s director of infrastructure services, and followed up by emailing links to those policies â€” terms that the company could change at any time. Bout of Google said that the tech company had â€œalways taken the compliance needs of our education users seriously.â€ Today, Googleâ€™s standard agreements with schools for its education apps include a commitment to comply with that law. Since adopting Google apps, Chicago schools have saved about $1.6 million annually on email and related costs, a district spokesperson said. *** In 2014, Googleâ€™s education juggernaut hit a speed bump in Chicago Public Schools. Google had hoped that Chicago would become an early adopter of Google Classroom, its new app to help teachers take attendance, assign homework and do other tasks. But Google had not anticipated Margaret Hahn. At the time, she was the school systemâ€™s director of technology change management. Early on, she said, Google had invited teachers to try an initial version of Classroom, without first contacting the school districtâ€™s technology administrators. Now Google wanted Chicago Public Schools to switch on the app districtwide, she said, before determining whether it complied with local student-protection policies. In an emailed statement, Bout said of the companyâ€™s core education services, â€œIn all cases, the use of these services is tied to the approval of an administrator who is responsible for overseeing a schoolâ€™s domain.â€ Google envisioned Classroom as a kind of â€œmission controlâ€ dashboard where teachers could more efficiently manage tasks such as assigning and correcting homework. To create the app, they collaborated closely with teachers. In May 2014, Google posted an announcement online, asking for volunteers to beta-test Classroom. More than 100,000 teachers worldwide responded, the company said. That August, Google made Classroom available to schools. That was too fast for Chicago Public Schools. Administrators there wanted to test Classroom first to make sure it complied with district policies and fit their teachersâ€™ needs. So they set up a pilot program, involving about 275 teachers and several thousand students, to run for the entire school year. Every month, Hahn said, she collected teachersâ€™ feedback and sent it to Google. One immediate problem administrators identified: School board policy required employees to keep records of cyberbullying and other problematic comments. But Classroom initially did not do that. If a student wrote something offensive and a teacher deleted it, there was no archive. Google eventually added an archiving feature. The next fall, the Chicago district switched on Classroom. Teachers there later vetted other Google products, effectively becoming a test lab for the company. Googleâ€™s ability to test its products on such a monumental scale has stoked concerns about whether the tech giant is exploiting public-school teachers and students for free labour. â€œItâ€™s a private company very creatively using public resources â€” in this instance, teachersâ€™ time and expertise â€” to build new markets at low cost,â€ said Patricia Burch, an associate professor of education at the University of Southern California. Rochelle, the Google executive, said that it was important for the company to have large, diverse sets of educational users giving feedback. â€œOur goal is to build products that help educators and students,â€ Rochelle said. â€œTeachers tell us they appreciate the opportunity to get involved early and help shape our products to meet their needs.â€ Read more about: Google, Apple, Microsoft Delivered dailyThe Morning HeadlinesÂ Newsletter Subscribe The Toronto Star and thestar.com, each property of Toronto Star Newspapers Limited, One Yonge Street, 4th Floor, Toronto, ON, M5EÂ 1E6. You can unsubscribe at any time. Please contact us or see our privacy policy for more information. DailyTimes | Google live streams Rahat Fateh Ali Khanâ€™s performance Toggle navigation Â Â Â Home Pakistan World Business Sport Life & Style Opinion Blogs Today's Paper E-PAPER Archives Google live streams Rahat Fateh Ali Khanâ€™s performance Rahat Fateh Ali Khan spoke at the Talks at Google event which was attended by influential thinkers, doers, creators and makers By: Â  Daily Times Monitor 14-May-17 Top News China to invest $50bn for mega dams in Pakistan 14-May-17 819 ISLAMABAD: In a first-of-its-k ... 10 labourers shot dead at Gwadar construction site 14-May-17 396 QUETTA: Gunmen on motorbikes o ... Google, the search engine giant, has streamed the performance of world-renowned Sufi singer Rahat Fateh Ali live on video-sharing website YouTube from its global headquarters in Mountain View, California, US. "We're excited to welcome Ustad Rahat Fateh Ali Khan for a Talks at Google event hosted by VP Anwar Akram," Google announced. Rahat Fateh Ali Khan spoke at the Talks at Google event which was attended by influential thinkers, doers, creators and makers. The event was live streamed at 10:30am. Building on a 600-year-old cultural legacy of Sufi music, Rahat Fateh Ali is the world-renowned for his work in Pakistani and Indian films and albums. Rahat Fateh Ali Khan is a Pakistani musician, primarily of Qawwali, a devotional music of the Muslim Sufis. He is the nephew of Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan and son of Farrukh Fateh Ali Khan and also the grandson of Qawwali singer Fateh Ali Khan. In addition to Qawwali, he also performs ghazals and other light music. He is also popular as a playback singer in Bollywood and the Pakistan film industry. Google is an American multinational technology company specialising in Internet-related services and products. These include online advertising technologies, search, cloud computing, software, and hardware. Google was founded in 1996 by Larry Page and Sergey Brin while they were PhD students at Stanford University, in California. Shockers High-yield Stocks The Best Blue-Chip Stocks AdChoices Google Maps uses Street View to keep you on the right path Engadget Nathan Ingraham 13 hrs ago SHARE SHARE TWEET SHARE EMAIL 25 iconic US brands that aren't made in America Why bottled water is one of the biggest scams of the century Â© Provided by Engadget Google Maps for Android got a slight remake this week, with a couple handy new features on board. It still looks and functions basically the same as the Google Maps you know and potentially love, but Google has smartly integrated some Street View features directly into the navigation view. When you ask the app for directions, you can swipe up from the bottom of the screen to see the all the turn-by-turn steps as before. But now each step is accompanied by a Street View image of that exact turn. Popular Searches Microsoft Corp MSFT â–¼ 68.38 -0.08 -0.12% If that sounds familiar, it's because Google added it to the web version of Maps many year ago, in 2008 in fact (as Android Police notes). Tapping on the Street View image opens it up full-screen, properly facing the direction you're going on the route. Most people are probably happy enough with the info provided by the turn-by-turn navigation, but if you're the type to get a little lost these images might help you prepare for the route. The default view when you pop open the Google Maps app has changed a bit, as well. Now, the bottom third or so of the screen contains info relevant to the time of day and your location, like local lunch spots. Google's had this location-specific info in Maps for a long time now; they're just surfacing it in a more obvious way here. These changes should all be available in Google Maps for Android now, but they haven't rolled out to the iOS app just yet. Given how Google is keen on keeping its apps in parity, these new features will likely hit the iPhone before long. Press Releases Newsletters Webinars ENTREPRENEUR Guest Can Googleâ€™s 20% time really work for your startup? David Mytton, Server Density@davidmytton May 13, 2017 2:33 PM Image Credit: dotshock/Shutterstock Googleâ€™s 20 percent time is one of the most famous, and arguably successful, management practices of all time. In their 2004 IPO letter, Googleâ€™s founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin revealed that the policy of allowing employees to take time out of their core jobs to be creative and experimental had led to some of the companyâ€™s most successful products. AdSense, which now accounts for about 25 percent of Googleâ€™s total revenue, Gmail, Google Transit and Google News were all born out of 20 percent time. Facebook, LinkedIn and Apple have all implemented their own versions of 20 percent time, but as huge and highly successful technology companies with money to spare, itâ€™s a bet they can afford to make. How does a small or medium sized business free up 20 percent of its employeesâ€™ time without jeopardizing the bottom line? Adapt to suit your business At Google employees are allowed to use their 20 percent time when they like, but in a small company a more planned approach may be necessary to ensure thereâ€™s always enough resource working on the core product or business. At Server Density we give our engineers a quota of one week out of every six to work on whatever they like, as long as itâ€™s relevant to the company; something we call a â€œrandom week.â€ This policy has resulted in some key product innovations for us. For example, one of our developers chose to use several of his random weeks over a period of several months to refactor and reimplement our server-monitoring time series graphing engine. We would get regular reports of minor graphing bugs, which were small on their own but added up to make our graphing a pain point for customers. We didnâ€™t focus on it in our usual roadmap because we had higher priority feature requests. After several of our larger customers made similar complaints, we decided to take our developerâ€™s random-week work and have the entire frontend team focus on it to completion. Guide how employees use their time It seems an obvious point, but the spirit of 20 percent time is to allow as much free rein to your employees as possible. Small businesses that need to keep a closer eye on return on time investment could set some parameters on how the time is used, or alternatively set up some kind of ranking of pain points that need solving within the business, with an incentive system for coming up with solutions. That way you can gently encourage creativity in the most useful direction. LinkedIn held regular hack days giving awards to people who wrote snippets of code quickly. Later they introduced the LinkedIn InCubator, where employees were allowed up to 90 days to work on a project, with check points at each month to check the projects were worthwhile. InCubator gave rise to a number of useful products, including a toolkit for pointing out new features as users move around the LinkedIn site. Encourage positive slacking When struggling with the idea of giving your employees one day in five, or whatever proportion of time you decide, to use as they wish, remember that no one is ever 100 percent productive with their time. By encouraging employees to work on side projects you are at least allowing them to â€œslack offâ€ productively. You will also ensure they feel valued and encourage a positive, engaged culture, especially if those projects then get incorporated into core (or new) products. Itâ€™s also a very good way to allow your team time to learn new technologies, improve their skills, and stay up to date with the industry. This can be difficult to achieve given how fast things move in tech and when formal â€œtrainingâ€ sessions and conferences can often be boring or not particularly useful. Although the graphing rewrite project at our company was started by one engineer as a way to move an old area of code from the Backbone to Facebookâ€™s React framework, the rest of the team also learned new techniques from the migration. Updating legacy code is always challenging. One of the engineers on the project wrote a blog post about the lessons learned; another was able to explore some complex color selection algorithms, an area of particular interest to her. What started as an engineering project crossed over to help our marketing team publish high quality content, which our customer success team is now using as part of an upcoming webinar to existing customers. The benefits can be seen across the business. Whatever system you come up with, encouraging creativity among your developers not only makes sound business sense from a product development point of view, it will also help you attract the best talent. A recent report from Stack Overflow ranked the opportunity for professional development as one of the top five job benefits for developers, so offering this policy will help with recruiting and retention, which, in todayâ€™s increasingly competitive market for talent, is almost reason enough. David Mytton is founder and CEO of Server Density.
bristolpostLoad mobile navigation News Bristol News Business Crime Education Health Politics Traffic & Travel History Celebs & TV Property Motoring Jobs UK & World NewsExpand What's On What's On News Family & Kids Film Food & Drink Music & Nightlife ShoppingExpand City Rovers Rugby In Your Area City Centre Clifton Fishponds Frenchay Knowle St Paul's See all locationsExpand Sign in Subscriptions Sign Out facebook twitter Book an ad Buy a photo Plus Rewards Crosswords Jobs Property Motors Buy/Sell Directory Family Notices Public Notices Dating InYourArea Contact Us About Us Competition Rules How to Complain Corrections and Clarifications Terms and Conditions Privacy Policy Cookie Policy RSS feeds Â© Local World frontpage News Bristol News Google News Google Earth Timelapse shows how much Bristol has changed over three decades Bristol from space - watch the city change before your eyes Â Share ByJoe Smith 18:29, 13 MAY 2017 Updated18:33, 13 MAY 2017 News Bristol has undergone a lot of change Â Share Ever wondered how Bristol's landscape has changed over the years? Thanks to NASA and Google Earth now you can watch the city grow and shift over the decades. The timelapse project was launched in partnership with NASA and several other research bodies and allows you to see how our planet has changed. Google combined over 5 million satellite images taken over the past three decades by 5 different satellites to give a picture of the changing face of our world since 1984. The images taken between 1984 and 2016 show how Bristol has changed including the addition of new housing estates and roads. Click below to watch Bristol change before your eyes. The images were originally collected as part of an ongoing joint mission between the United States Geological Survey (USGS) and NASA called Landsat. Since the 1970s, the Landsat mission's satellites have been observing the Earth from space. Google started working with the USGS in 2009 to make this historic archive of earth imagery available online. Read More Haunting documents just discovered show horrific extent of Bristol's links with slave trade So now you have another way to waste hours of your time on Google Earth. As well as overhead satellite views of the city, you can also virtually visit areas of Bath to see how the roads themselves have changed over the years. Hereâ€™s some examples of recent Google Street View changesâ€¦ The Cenotaph The roads around the cenotaph have seen huge works taking place in recent years. The new layout in the city centre will hopefully ease congestion and allow the new metrobus to run smoothly but it has created a building site in the meantime. The Cenotaph in 2008 looked a little different... These days it's a little harder to see the cenotaph Stokes Croft Stokes Croft has seen massive changes since 2008. The building that was to become the Hamilton House and the Canteen - the hip eatery at the heart of Bristol's self-styled 'cultural quarter' - was still an abandoned former office block back then. Read More Old Market roundabout to close as escalator buildings and footbridge finally demolished These days the street is a thriving strip of bars and cafÃ©s famous for its graffiti - note the break dancing Jesus mural. Back when the Canteen was just another empty office block These days it's a Stokes Croft institution Feeder Road The plans for Bristol's new arena have seen the construction of an impressive new bridge on the site of the former council pest control and dog warden services. Whether anything will be built at the end of that bridge remains to be seen. Feeder Road was a bit of a backwater before plans were passed for the new stadium Now it's a backwater with a bridge to nowhere on it... A Sunday People investigation reveals the online fraudsters lure travellers with Â­ fake Â­websites created with photos and descriptions stolen from genuine sites. They set up a pay-per-click arrangement with Google for key words such as â€œBalearic villasâ€, meaning their company is listed at the top of the search engine. But after thousands of pounds are handed over â€“ encouraged by discounts for payment in full â€“ the deception unfolds when contact dries up. A genuine website listing for a property in Crete A fake website listing for the same property We launched our probe after the police Action Fraud reporting centre revealed that more than 100 people a week are being cheated out of their holidays. Dozens only realise they have been duped when they travel to properties and find them occupied by customers who have booked via the real companies. Nearly 6,000 victims lost Â£7.2million to cloned holiday websites last year, a rise of 20 per cent on 2015. One slick website, Canaries Holiday Villas, claims to create â€œthe perfect holiday experience for youâ€. It boasts of hundreds of properties scattered across the Canary Islands Â­including â€œVilla Azaleriaâ€, a four-bedroom house with a pool in Lanzarote. A fake website for a property in Majorca The real website for the Majorca property After emailing the site, our investigator was told: â€œI am pleased to inform you that I have availability of the villa for your dates 18 to 25 June. â€œThe total cost is Â£1,800, plus deposit of Â£500 fully refundable on inspection of property after departure. â€œTo confirm the reservation you have 2 options â€“ total prepayment with a Â­discount of 10 per cent or payment of the 50% + security deposit and the balance 3 weeks before arrival.â€ The site also boasts: â€œWith our 7 years experience, our knowledge worldwide means you can relax from the moment you choose one of our villas and we will do the rest for you. â€œYou can book with confidence as our properties are verified by us for your peace of mind.â€ In fact, this is a claim they have stolen from a genuine holiday company, Villas Away, as well as images and words from a range of legitimate villa firms, including Villa Plus, based in St Albans. Pictures of â€œstaffâ€ had been lifted from genuine businesses. A fake website for a Canary Islands property with a fake contact listed The real profile of the contact for the property The supposed Â­property manager is identical to an Australian real estate company staff member. Despite claiming to be in operation for seven years, the site Canariesholidayvillas.com was only registered six months ago. Villa Plus co-owner Nick Cooper confirmed the â€œVilla Azaleriaâ€ Â­property in Lanzarote was on his books as Villa Azurra and is unavailable for the week we had been Â­offered by the scammers. He said: â€œIt is a real battle against the crooks and sometimes I feel as if I am the only person trying to shut them down. â€œTaxi drivers started telling us about customers turning up at our properties earlier this year, only to find out that they had be ripped off by these websites. Most find out when details fail to materialise but some have been stranded overseas. It is shocking that they are able to get away with this.â€ Villa Plus co-owner Nick Cooper says it is a battle to fight the crooks Mr Cooperâ€™s company rents out 1,500 properties and believes some 5,000 of their websiteâ€™s Â­images have been cloned. Our probe found Balearic Villa Escapes, Rent Holiday Villas and Greek Villa Escapes operate in the same way as Canaries Holiday Villas. A week in June at Casa Lluna, a four-bedroom apartment on a hill above Pollenca, in Majorca, costs Â£4,596. But the crooks behind Balearic Villa Escapes, who pay Google to be top of the search engine, offered the property to our reporter for Â£3,150, after lifting the words and photos from Simpson Travel. They emailed to reassure our reporter the booking will be made under their bogus â€œPeace of Mind Payment Protectionâ€ scheme and directed her to a page on their site which said it only applies for a â€œwire bank transfer directly to the owner bank accountâ€. Families are urged to investigate a website before making any bookings (stock photo) (Photo: Getty) After getting a scan of her passport and full address, Balearic Villa Escapes sent our investigator a professional-looking contract asking for full payment into the account of Pavel Sandor. It had been set up with Cashplus bank, which boasts on its site that a current Â­account can be â€œopened within four Â­minutesâ€ and doesnâ€™t let a â€œcredit check get in the wayâ€. Simpson Travel, of south-west London, said: â€œThis Casa Lluna apartment has been cloned from our site and promoted by an unscrupulous company. We will be taking legal action. â€œWe are extremely concerned potential customers are being deceived and urge customers to do their research and ensure that they book with a bonded villa operator.â€ Nick Cooper, of Villa Plus, added: â€œI warned about Greek Villa Escapes by starting a TripAdvisor thread last month. Read More Brit holiday-makers paying up to FOUR times the cost of their plane ticket for European airport transfers â€œBut the crooks complained and Trip Advisor responded by banning my Â­account and deleting all the warnings, despite me showing clear evidence that they are crooks. â€œAfter 30 years in this industry, Iâ€™ve never seen such a disgraceful attitude by big companies to consumer protection.â€ Fraudsters also increasingly target popular sites such as Owners Direct, Airbnb and HomeAway, which list Â­hundreds of holiday homes to rent. Crooks either hack into these sites or list a number of fake properties to tempt customers to hand over cash. Charlotte Banks, 34, of Horley, Surrey, was looking forward to a hen party after her group of friends rented a house in Cornwall via Owners Direct. Ten days before arrival, she called the property owner to arrange a late checkout â€“ to find there was no record of the booking and heâ€™d never heard of her party. She said: â€œThe owner was a phishing victim whoâ€™d had his emails hacked by a fraudster who intercepted my friendâ€™s inquiry via the online booking form. Fraudsters also increasingly target popular sites such as Owners Direct, Airbnb and HomeAway (stock photo) (Photo: Getty) â€œThe fraudster replied pretending to be the home owner and my friend handed over the best part of Â£1,500. â€œMy friend reported it to the police. Her account is with Barclays and the money was paid into an account at the same bank, set up with fake Â­details â€“ but there was nothing they could do either.â€ This week, City of London Police National Fraud Intelligence Bureau launches a campaign to beat the bogus Â­holiday companies. It is acting in conjunction with the Association of British Travel Agents and information website Get Safe Online. Campaigners warn the official toll of fraud victims is probably just the tip of the iceberg. They say embarrassment at being duped means many of those affected fail to report scams. Action Fraudâ€™s deputy head Steve Proffitt said: â€œThe Â­impact of falling victim to holiday fraud can be far greater than the financial loss. â€œWe hope that by raising awareness, people will feel better able to protect themselves from being a victim of fraud. â€œWe urge anyone who believes they have been a fraud victim to visit Â­actionfraud.police.uk and report the incident.â€ Canaries Holiday Villas, Greek Villa Escapes and Balearic Villa Escapes are hosted by the US organisation GoDaddy. Ben Butler, director of the Digital Crimes Unit at GoDaddy, said: â€œWe communicate regularly with UK law enforcement on alleged fraud issues and have established processes in place for taking action against websites conducting illegal activity. Read More Brit holidaymakers scammed out of Â£7.2MILLION last year by online booking fraudsters â€œIf anyone believes that they have been defrauded by the people operating these websites, they should contact law enforcement.â€ Balearic Villa Escapes said the Council of Spain had issued it with a rental licence and gave an address in a residential part of Ibiza. A TripAdvisor spokesman said: â€œWe are currently conducting an investigation into the concerns raised about the alleged fake holiday rental sites. â€œWhile the forum posts in question had not met our guidelines and were removed from the site, given the unique circumstances, the ban on Mr Cooperâ€™s account has now been lifted.â€ A Google spokesman was unavailable to comment on its pay-per-click arrangements. How to avoid these rip-offs Many people are gearing up for a summer holiday but it's important to be careful when booking online (stock photo) â–  Check the web address is legitimate and has not been altered by slight changes to a domain name, such as going from .co.uk to .org â–  Do a thorough online search to check the companyâ€™s credentials. If a company is defrauding there is a good chance victims will post details of their experiences. â–  Look for the logo â€“ check whether the company is a member of a recognised trade body such as the Association of British Travel Agents. You can verify membership at www.abta.com â–  Never pay directly into a private individualâ€™s bank account. Paying by direct bank transfer is like paying by cash â€“ the money is very difficult to trace and not refundable. Wherever possible, pay by credit or debit card. â–  Check paperwork. You should study receipts, invoices and terms and conditions. Be wary of any companies that donâ€™t provide any at all. When booking through a holiday club or timeshare, have the contract thoroughly vetted by a solicitor before signing up. â–  Trust your instincts. If something sounds too good to be true, it probably is. â–  Report it. Expect that number to grow at I/O 2017. Project Tango and AR We could see more news about Googleâ€™s Project Tango, a self-contained augmented reality platform, at I/O 2017. The impressive software-sensor combo can track objects, walls, and table surfaces in three-dimensional space. The best Project Tango apps and games enableÂ computer-generated characters to bounce on top of nearby tables, virtual drapes to draw closed over real-world windows, and digital dominoes to topple onto physical floorboards. But hardware partners havenâ€™t been quick on the uptake. The first consumer-oriented Tango phone, Lenovoâ€™s Tango-equipped Phab 2 Pro launched last year, and the Asus ZenFone AR Tango Phone, doesnâ€™t have a release date. Itâ€™s been pretty quiet on the Tango front, but weâ€™re hoping to hear more about Tango hardware â€” and related software â€” at I/O 2017.
