Google Pixel long-term review: Still the best smartphone I've ever used David Ruddock Follow View All Posts 2017/05/02 3:28pm PDTMay 2, 2017 76 Plus 1 on G+ 342 Share on Facebook 126 Share on Twitter Total Shares544 News Phone Reviews Pixel Pixel XL Article Contents 1 The hardware 2 Battery life 3 Display, audio, and wireless 4 Camera 5 Performance and software 6 Value 7 Conclusion I have been using the Google Pixel XL for six months now. Not continuously, mind you - I have taken breaks here and there. But after using the Galaxy S8+, the LG G6, and the OnePlus 3T, there is only one phone I've instinctively found myself returning to, and it's this one. Google's Pixel isn't without its flaws; in fact, it has a great many I can cite with ease. The Bluetooth connectivity sucks. The back of the phone has very obvious wear rub. The glass window scratches easily. It's not waterproof. 'OK Google' hotword detection breaks for no apparent reason, necessitating a reboot. The fingerprint scanner is slower than what you'd find on a number of competitor devices. The value proposition is mediocre at best. The screen to body ratio pales in comparison to phones like the G6 or Galaxy S8. And you can't even buy the damn thing. Why do I keep picking up the Pixel time and time again, then? Am I just a brainwashed Google fanboy (don't answer that question)? The answer is consistency. In the nearly seven years I've been doing this, I have never used an Android phone that has held up so well to the tortures of time. The Pixel XL feels nearly as smooth as the day I began using it six months ago. Android glides along with best-in-class touch latency and a responsiveness that feels immediate (if not manic) and satisfying. It's not just performance, either. My battery life remains largely predictable, too, and largely very good. The camera continues to impress with its swift launches and ease of use, and it produces the most consistently excellent results of any smartphone camera I have ever used. HDR+ is easily, for me, the best smartphone camera feature out there. Oh, and even if the fingerprint scanner is a bit slow compared to some, at least the damn thing is easy to reach and reads consistently. Is the XL worth $770 to pick up today? I don't really think so, let alone $870 for the 128GB version we all actually want. And honestly, I have a hard time seeing the point of the smaller 5" model at $650 right now, that just feels like lunacy. The XL offers better battery life and is far from "big phone" status in terms of actual usability - it's really the only one of the two that warrants consideration, in my opinion. With that, let's dive in to the details. The hardware Put the Google Pixel XL next to a Galaxy S8+ and you'll have a pretty hard time finding much to love about Google's phone. 2017 is ushering in a new era of smartphone design language and packaging, and the Pixel XL clearly hails from the period prior to that shift. To be fair, it did come out six months ago. But there's no doubt that from an industrial design point of view, the Pixel is aging fairly rapidly. The 5.5" Pixel XL is nearly as tall as a Galaxy S8+, but the latter has a 6.2" display. Line up the bottom of the S8's screen with the Pixel XL's, and it becomes apparent just how much more panel Samsung has managed to shove into a frame that is only a few millimeters taller. Granted, this does have ergonomic consequences (the S8+ is unabashedly more difficult to use one-handed than the XL because of the screen's height), but I think it's safe to say most of us want more screen where we can get it. I still think the Pixel XL is perfectly nice to hold and like the texture of the aluminum opposed to Samsung and LG's new glass-heavy designs. I also still believe the fingerprint scanner is in the ideal location, unlike the Galaxy S8, which has the most frustrating one in existence. The position of the camera makes accidental smudging less likely, too, and I really like the perfectly flush look Google was able to achieve with the glass window. Visible wear lines on the casing In terms of wear and tear, my XL has... not fared well. The finish on the Quite black model I have here has begun to very noticeably rub off in areas where the aluminum chassis is slightly more raised than others. You could remedy this with a skin, but I personally like this phone totally unadorned. Otherwise, though, it's held up well - the buttons are still fine and I don't notice any real physical problems with the phone aside from the aforementioned finish wear. Just don't drop it in the toilet. Battery life As I said in the introduction, it's consistently good. I always have a pretty clear sense of how much time I've got left when I'm really starting to push my XL to the limits of its longevity. If I'm having a Wi-Fi heavy day with lots of using the phone for browsing the web and texting, 5 hours of screen-on time is doable. If I'm away from home and largely on LTE, I can pretty reliably get 4 hours of screen time assuming it's not stretched over much longer than a 12-hour period. For a full 16-hour day away from wall outlets and going it on mobile data alone, 3 hours is what I generally end up managing. This probably won't impress many of you with Xiaomi, Huawei, or Exynos-powered Samsung devices, and I understand that. But the thing about the Pixel has been just how well I've been able to learn what I can expect in terms of battery performance based on the conditions I'm using it in. I know I can throw in a bit of tethering and Bluetooth streaming without completely obliterating the battery, for example, if I'm at 60% halfway through my day and won't top up till later that evening. My range anxiety with the Pixel is exceptionally low, even if it doesn't offer the very best battery life of any smartphone. Would I like the next-generation Pixels to have larger batteries? Yes, please. Relying only on software to ensure a good power consumption experience is missing half the equation (and I'm not saying that's what Google did). Stuffing even a few-hundred more milliamp hours of capacity in there can be the difference between a dead phone and one that gets you back to the charger at the end of the night. Always fit a bigger battery when you can. Display, audio, and wireless The Super AMOLED Quad HD display still looks bright and crisp, even if the new panel on the S8 is clearly a cut above the part Google is using on the Pixel. Even so, I think the screen is one area where the Pixel XL earns its $770 keep, as there really aren't many phones out there you're going to find which are considerably better in this regard unless they have "Galaxy" inscribed on the back. On the audio front, I found the Pixel's bottom-firing speaker mediocre at the time I reviewed it, and I find it mediocre today. Sadly, it's not getting much in the way of competition, either - both the G6 and S8 have speakers that are at least as unimpressive, if not worse in certain respects, and I hope Google can at least give us that quasi-BoomSound using the earpiece speaker on the Pixel 2 this year. The headphone jack offers performance in line with most Snapdragon 820-series devices and thus isn't the best candidate for pushing your high-impedance cans, but I find it perfectly serviceable in the gym even at high outputs. The quality is there, even if this generation of Qualcomm parts didn't offer as much power as audiophiles probably would have liked. One of my biggest gripes about the XL is its Bluetooth performance. I have used three separate Pixel XLs, and all of them have absolutely terrible Bluetooth signal. Even think about touching the phone in the wrong spot, and the music stream to your headphones or car will cut out. It is absolutely obnoxious. It doesn't matter what kind of headphones, speaker, or car A/V unit - it sucks with anything I've tried. Even walking around with the Pixel XL in my pocket connected to a pair of Bluetooth headphones results in cuts every single time I step up a stair or rest my hand against the pocket the phone is in. The 7.1.2 patch has done nothing to alleviate this issue. It's borderline embarrassing: I have had the Pixel XL corrupt the Bluetooth profiles on my car three times. Each time, the only solution was to factory reset the infotainment unit. I had to factory reset my car. No other phone has ever done this to me, though since the 7.1.2 update this hasn't happened - yet. Wi-Fi performance, on the other hand, has been quite excellent for me, and LTE signal is at least as good as most other phones I tested in 2016. Now that I'm on Verizon, I'm even getting some HD voice calls, which is such a huge upgrade in terms of the call experience. But seriously, Google: get the damn Bluetooth right next time. Camera I can't stop taking pictures with the Pixel. I love this camera. No more words: just photos. Â  Â  Performance and software Aside from the aforementioned Bluetooth problems, you know what I find so wonderful about the Pixel? I rarely really get annoyed using it. Apps load up at consistently quick speeds, the OS always feels snappy and responsive, and the touch latency is positively iPhone-y. Like your finger is truly controlling the elements on the screen. The home button and back key respond lightning-quick, in a way that almost starts to make them feel like real buttons. I struggle to really convey how right Google got the basic "interacting with the phone" stuff here. What they managed to do with the Pixel will only make the Pixel 2 that much better a phone, and I will be clear: I do not feel this way about the Galaxy S8. The Pixel feels incredibly natural and pleasant to interact with. There are still hiccups, delays, and little areas where things just don't feel as smooth and seamless as they should on the S8. Google nailed this. No other phone I've used has. Is the Pixel as fast in a straight-line speed sense as a OnePlus 3T? No. But counting fractional differences between the number of seconds it takes to load an app or how long before it's pushed out of memory are not methods that convey an experience. They tell you a couple of very specific things under a controlled circumstance. In practice, I simply find the Pixel the most consistent and smooth Android smartphone I've ever used. But, it does have some usability issues. For one, my 'OK Google' hotword detection breaks basically once a week, necessitating a reboot. I use this when in the car, and so it's very, very inconvenient when this happens. Rebooting the phone takes a good minute-plus, and then it has to reconnect to my Bluetooth (which is never guaranteed to work). This is probably something to do with the Google app, but it's annoying nonetheless. Other than that? I struggle to find anything about the software that I really dislike. Most of my frustrations come down to third-party apps, not the Pixel. And those are annoying on any phone I use. Value When it debuted in October, the Google Pixel XL cost $770. The one you and I actually want, the 128GB model, cost $870. Six months later, the Pixel XL still costs $870. Is it worth it? Hah. No. The successor devices to the current Pixel family will be unveiled in the next five or six months. There is absolutely no good reason to shell out what, with tax, amounts to nearly a thousand dollars for this smartphone. You will absolutely regret it the moment Google announces the Pixel 2 - I guarantee you. Do not buy a Pixel right now. In fact, I'd say just don't buy a Pixel period anymore, we're just too close to the next iteration for that to be remotely sane advice. Conclusion So, that's weird, right? I can't even recommend that you buy what is easily my favorite Android smartphone currently on the market? What kind of long-term endorsement is that? That's because for all its problems and limited availability, the last six months I've used the Pixel have utterly proven to me that Google is capable of building a smartphone that, from a user experience standpoint, rises above the competition. Google's unmatched ability to optimize the way Android and the underlying phone parts interact is very much a reason I love this phone so much. A smartphone should get out of its own way when you use it - it should be an effortless canvas upon which your fingers and eyes naturally engage and interact. That means it should be fast. It should be consistent. And it should just feel right to use. I know that some of these things don't really translate well into concrete assessments, but there's something about the Pixel that really just works for me so well. It's as close to my ideal smartphone as I've ever been. I'm hoping that Google smoothes over some of the rough edges not just with the phone, but with the whole experience of buying and owning it. Why is is to hard to buy a Pixel? It's positively ridiculous just how bad Google has been at keeping this phone in stock. I also think it's hard to ignore that in 2017, the Pixel's design language and overall look and feel are clearly behind the competition. This looks like yesterday's smartphone, and even on the day it was announced it was kind of hard to really fall in love with in an aesthetic sense. At best, it's just kind of boring. Post-purchase experiences should improve, too. Google's online and live chat support are very-just-OK, and what I've heard of the RMA process hasn't been super reassuring - full price credit card holds and iffy-quality refurbished replacements. Of course, that's what happens when you're in the online-only phone sales business. Still, Google should be working to streamline defect, warranty, and accidental damage claims in a way that makes it feel like the nearly-thousand dollars you spent on your phone is going into supporting a thousands-dollar-phone experience. They really also need to stop making crappy cases that are obscenely overpriced. Google made a great phone when it built the Pixel. Now Google needs to be a great phone company. I'm curious to see if they can pull it off. Tags google pixel long term review google pixel review pixel long term review pixel xl long term review subscribe ... Straight away it's hit two areas out of the park that matter to most people. At launch it had a class leading SoC that continues to offer great performance. It has plenty of RAM. Rock solid build quality. A super fast and accurate fingerprint sensor. USB-C (remember the GS7 didn't which was Samsung's 2017 flagship) with fast-charging and excellent battery life. It has the most capable voice assistant. It's got the latest version of Android and what I believe to be the best overall user experience for most people - it's consistently fast and smooth, unlike anything from Samsung, and will receive timely updates for much longer than the competition. The Pixel is the iPhone of the Android world and I think it has a market to fill. Do I think the Pixel 2 needs to be better? You bet. No one is denying this. What phone doesn't need to be better than its predecessor? If the Pixel 2 doesn't at least have waterproofing and a higher display-to-bezel ratio critics will hold them to account. But I'm pretty sure these features are a guarantee. The thing is, and I've said this elsewhere, I don't really consider a lot of the hardware bells and whistles we see from the likes of Samsung all that meaningful. The curved display is a gimmick. It looks great, but I'm not at all sold from a functional perspective. The same with the new 18:9 ratio. For a mobile device I consider one handed usability important. Reaching the notification pull-down with one hand is already a no-go on the GS8 and its fingerprint sensor is another ergonomic mis-step. And a heart rate sensor? Who on earth uses this? Same goes with its iris-scanner and face recognition. Why use these options when a well positioned fingerprint sensor is more convenient? It's all just guff. Bullet points for carrier salespeople to sing about in store. I think waterproofing is a biggie though. Google can't drop the ball here. I also think wireless charging is going to become significant if Apple introduces it to their new iPhone. We've seen Google offer wireless charging in the past and then take it away because, well, I don't think that many people really cared. But I sense the tide is going to turn on this. Google's phone is priced the same as the iPhone and Galaxy S because it's being positioned as a premium product. I hate the word "premium". It's huge BS when you really think about it. But ultimately this is the strategy Google is taking with its new phone. A high margin, high performing, premium flagship for the masses. I think the best of the Pixel line is yet to come. Knowledgeborn Allah I also think the Pixel launched with a lot of good qualities and features, and that's why I rushed to purchase it. However, around the same time, I bought an iPhone 7+, just to give iOS a fair shot. Now that I've used both devices, I think it's a huge mistake to call the Pixel "the iPhone of the Android world". In reality, it doesn't even come close, and that's where the problem comes in. The iPhone is Apple's primary device when it comes to sales, but it can almost be seen as an accessory to other Apple devices, like the Mac and the iPad, etc. The Apple ecosystem allows all their devices to work together seamlessly through Continuity, and this is something Android can't replicate (at least not at this point in time). The Pixel may look similar to an iPhone, but it definitely doesn't function like one. And yes, I know that Samsung (and carriers) puts a bunch of bloat on their devices, showing off features that many people will never use. The difference, though, is all about opportunity and selection. Samsung built an entire brand around giving their consumers more than they'll ever ask for, and that's what keeps those customers coming back. I don't know anybody who uses that heart-rate sensor on the back. When I see it, I think, "Why wouldn't they remove that and use the idea of the heart-rate monitor to sell more Galaxy Gear smartwatches?" I just didn't get it... But, hypothetically, if somebody ever ends up in a situation where they need a heart-rate monitor, Samsung has them covered. I learned that firsthand when my nephew was taken to his school nurse due to an asthma attack, and the nurse didn't have a heart-rate monitor in her office. Her assistant pulled out his Galaxy S7 Edge and used the heart-rate monitor on there to relay it to medical services when they arrived. I know, that would be a generally rare occurrence, but it happens from time to time, enough for people to consider what would happen if they didn't have it. Personally, I don't think Google has enough "skin in the game" at this point to really charge that much for the Pixel. Apple and Samsung have proven brands in the smartphone space. Tech reviewers giving it high marks isn't going to matter too much among average consumers, because most people just aren't interested in technology to that extent. They just want something that works, and works reliably. Google hasn't demonstrated the ability to make hardware that just works reliably (unless you count the Chromebook Pixel line, which most people didn't buy either). It's always better to start at the bottom and work your way up, than to start at the top and get knocked all the way down. A major reason why many people buy high end premium products is BECAUSE they're expensive. Marketing 101 mate. Phones are modern day status symbols. I remember when the Pixel launched some people scoffed at the price and said "well I'm just gonna wait for Google to discount it in a few months". I tried to tell these people that it wasn't going to happen and that the best "bang for buck" time to buy the Pixel was actually launch day. And here we are, months later, and the Pixel is still being positioned as a high end premium product. And believe me, it'll still be priced at the high end right up until the Pixel 2 launches. You're correct in saying that many people buy high end products because high prices give the illusion of inherent quality. The problem, however, is that the Pixel is competing against the iPhone, and it hasn't worked. In fact, it can't and won't work. There aren't any Android OEMs who can realistically compete with Apple. They may design devices that compete with the iPhone, but they can't compete with Apple. Why? For starters, continuity. When you buy a Pixel device, you're buying a product. When you buy an iPhone, you're buying into the Apple brand and ecosystem, where all their devices, ranging from the Apple Watch to the Mac to the iPad, iPod Touch and Apple TV, and even AirPods and Beats wireless headphones, all work seamlessly together. Secondly, you're buying into the Apple Store and it's customer service benefits. Thirdly, you're buying into Apple's update cycles, which come directly from Apple to all their devices instantaneously and average around 4-5 years of support. The list goes on and on. Google isn't naive. They have their own ecosystem, but it's centered around their software and services, which you can get on practically any device. They don't have a hardware ecosystem. They knew what they were getting into, and they took a chance by trying to compete directly with the iPhone in pricing. They also see that it's clearly not working, so it's time for them to adopt a new strategy. If they actually want large groups of people buying their devices, which I'm not entirely sure they do, they either need to have standout features like Samsung Galaxy devices (which they don't), or they need to lower their prices. Right now, lowering the price on the Pixel is the only way they can salvage it. whispy_snippet I disagree on many levels. You don't establish yourself as a hardware company overnight, and you don't establish a product's premium reputation overnight. Yes, Google doesn't have the same hardware ecosystem Apple has at this stage. But they've now got skin in the game that matters most - phones. All of the products you listed from Apple don't come close to the significance of the phone. Many will never own an Apple TV, a MacBook, or Airpods. But almost everyone owns a phone - and we don't know where hardware is going to take us next. Maybe in a few years time tablets will be dead, everyone will be using hybrids and home assistants will be one of the most important gadgets in our lives. Who knows? The point is just because Google doesn't have the same suite of products as Apple doesn't mean they won't one day, or that they won't be the company that leads the pack in the hardware that matters tomorrow. Further to this, just because the Pixel lives in an ecosystem different to the iPhone doesn't mean it can't be a success in its own right. Google is known for its class leading services. What happens if it starts gradually making these hugely important and much loved services - like Google Maps, Google Drive, YouTube, Google Photos... even Google Search - Pixel exclusives? It sounds improbable - almost impossible! But it serves as a reminder of how powerful and influential Google is in the services EVERYONE uses, Apple customers included. Google entered the hottest fight in consumer tech and delivered a hugely impressive smartphone on its first attempt. It wasn't perfect, but it bettered the competition in a number of important ways. Who knows what Google has in store for the Pixel 2, 3 or 4? They're in this for the long haul. You can't expect the Pixel to sell like the iPhone and Galaxy S in its first, second or perhaps even third iteration. But as time goes by, the Pixel will stand shoulder to shoulder with Apple and Samsung's best in the minds of the average consumer. There's too much at stake for Google to sit this one out. Knowledgeborn Allah I think you're missing my point... I'm not saying Pixel can't be a success. It definitely can be, but Google needs a better strategy to make that happen. When you're competing against a company that has a structured, proven hardware ecosystem that seemingly locks users in, you have to do something extraordinary to break them out. Samsung is doing that by releasing groundbreaking smartphones. OnePlus is doing that by undercutting flagship devices via pricing. What's Google doing? The idea that Google has leverage because of their services is naive at best. Google isn't going to make their services exclusive to the Pixel or its brand because they make too much money from their portals. If they restricted YouTube to the Pixel, everybody would switch to Vimeo or something else, and Google's stock would plummet. The same goes for pretty much all their other services too. The only leverage they have is in financing, and that's very comparable to Apple anyway. In fact, I think Apple may actually be worth MORE than Google at the moment. In reality, Google will never try to conquer the hardware space. Services are their moneymaker, and the more devices they can attach their web services to, the better it is for their bottom line. That's what it's really about, at the end of the day: money. The Nexus program was more popular than the Pixel, even though there was far less advertising for it, because Google implemented a strategy of undercutting their competition. They probably thought that meant people just loved their devices and decided to launch a "premium" product. In reality, one of the main selling points of the Nexus line was its affordability. The Pixel doesn't have that, and that's why it's not selling. Again, they need to undercut their competition in pricing, or they need to implement standout features that are exclusive to the Pixel. I see those as the only sure ways to salvage the disaster that is the Pixel line right now. whispy_snippet Maybe grab yourself a cup of tea... â€œI think you're missing my point... Google has a huge advantage on the cloud service side of the equation - an advantage that I think is going to prove increasingly valuable in the coming years. â€œIn reality, Google will never try to conquer the hardware space. Services are their moneymaker, and the more devices they can attach their web services to, the better it is for their bottom line. That's what it's really about, at the end of the day: money. The Nexus program was more popular than the Pixel, even though there was far less advertising for it, because Google implemented a strategy of undercutting their competition. They probably thought that meant people just loved their devices and decided to launch a "premium" product. In reality, one of the main selling points of the Nexus line was its affordability. The Pixel doesn't have that, and that's why it's not selling. Again, they need to undercut their competition in pricing, or they need to implement standout features that are exclusive to the Pixel. I see those as the only sure ways to salvage the disaster that is the Pixel line right now.â€ Google is trying to conquer the hardware space right now. Chromecast, Chromecast Audio, Google WiFi, Google Home, the Pixel, Daydream, Chromebooks, the hiring of Rick Osterloh as SVP of hardware - thereâ€™s evidence of Googleâ€™s push into hardware everywhere. But you donâ€™t usurp hardware empires like Apple or Samsung with the click of the fingers. This is a long game, one that is going to rage for years to come. If Google continues to develop the Pixel at the same rate itâ€™s developing its services (and by all indications this is Googleâ€™s intention) its phone will be a formidable force sooner than you think. The unrefined, â€œrushedâ€ gen-one Pixel won critical acclaim from tech sites and bloggers everywhere - for example Android Police, The Verge, and MKBHD all rated the Pixel one of the best smartphones one could buy when it launched. Labelling the Pixel line a â€œdisasterâ€ is as laughable as it is bizarre. Clearly itâ€™s selling well as Google is having huge trouble keeping it in stock. And yeah, part of this is because Google is botching its supply train, but teething issues were to be expected. The message to take home from these issues is that thereâ€™s a demand for Googleâ€™s first phone. It is selling. Not at iPhone or Galaxy S levels, of course. Not yet. But anyone with a reasonable appreciation of the smartphone industry never expected it would. But I would definitely expect the Pixel 2 to sell better than its first gen sibling. Onward and upward. Youâ€™d be foolish to underestimate the second most valuable company in the world. Knowledgeborn Allah You're making some really good points... But I highly doubt Google is not trying to conquer the hardware space. They may be merging themselves into the hardware space, but dominating it? That kind of growth would eventually make them a virtual monopoly! They'd be shut down before they reached that point. There can be groundbreaking features of a device without them revolutionizing the way we use our devices. Based on your presentation, the only groundbreaking device on the market would be the BlackBerry KeyONE, since that literally changes the way someone would use their smartphone, at least a modern one. And, by the way, I'm not calling the Pixel a disaster in and of itself. I'm talking about its sales figures when compared to its competition. It's a pretty good device. I've had several issues with mine, and it's been far from perfect, but it's definitely not horrible. However, money is what matters at the end of the day. It's priced in the same range as the iPhone and Galaxy devices. Yet, it hasn't sold in numbers even remotely comparable to either of those. That's what I meant by it being a "disaster". whispy_snippet Apple has long dominated hardware. Why wouldn't Google aspire to be in this position one day? Why would Google be stopped when Apple wasn't? If Google sees an opportunity for growth that they're confident they can exploit they're almost obligated to go for it and provide returns for investors. Google may not ever reach a dominant position but I've no doubt its long term goal is to dominate. Just on the Pixel's sales figures, I'd reiterate that looking at gen one sales compared to the iPhone or Galaxy S is pointless. It really is. It's certain that many people still don't even know that the Pixel exists. What we need to keep an eye on is its growth. Will the Pixel 2 sell more than the first gen Pixel? Will the Pixel 3 do the same again? Will this growth be at the expense of Apple and Samsung market share? Just watch this space. I'm expecting it will definitely keep doing better in the years ahead. But it's going to be a fight. Knowledgeborn Allah I also think that the Pixel will see growth, year over year, at least initially. It's not going to be easy, though, regardless of Google's resources, because they're still going up against Samsung in the Android space. Personally, I think Samsung is going to crush the Android smartphone space for years to come, and there's not much Google can really do about that. The competing spaces, at least right now, are reserved for iOS and Android, and Samsung has gotten the dominant position in Android to become Apple's biggest competitor in the smartphone space. It took them years to get there, and I highly doubt they'd let that position be handed over to Google. The Pixel will be in a better position to secure the dominant position in the Android space if Samsung decides to start using their Tizen OS. Until then, Google will be fighting an uphill battle against Samsung, and they'll pretty much always lose. whispy_snippet We'll see won't we. Knowledgeborn Allah Indeed. Jarrett Lennon Kaufman A few thoughts/counters, in both directions, from my own experience: 1. I have had NONE of these Bluetooth problems you described with any device, including several different headsets as well as my car. I can travel notable distances from it, work out with it, and no disconnects. BUT, I have a Pixel, not an XL. Could that somehow be a factor? 2. Warranty service, for me, was exemplary. Yes, there was a credit card hold, but I'm used to that for advance exchanges. Otherwise it was a 10-minute process via chat, the replacement arrived in two days and was flawless, and thanks to the overall Pixel backup/restore process, the transition was painless. Easiest warranty exchange ever. Also, she allowed me to decide, on my own, to skip going through a factory reset as we both felt I'd done enough of my own troubleshooting. 3. Now the bad one: my Pixel freezes on me semi-regularly. On the one I replaced it was sometimes several times a day, but on the replacement, after about two weeks of use, it's as much as once a day, as infrequently as once every two days. Full-on hard freeze necessitating holding the power button until it reboots. NOT good. Never had this happen before or anything like it on a previous phone. Clearly, if it survived the warranty replacement, it's an app causing it. But how can an app consistently freeze up the entire system to this degree? What's not preventing that? And why is there no easy way to troubleshoot that? This is really bugging me and is the only thing damaging what's an otherwise stunning, stellar phone that's my favorite of all time. Only other disappointment for me is not having an XL which is what I wanted at launch, but the store approved me for just under enough money to get a 128GB XL. I had to choose between 32GB XL or 128GB non, and 128GB was (and still is) more important to me. But I'd rather have the better battery life and higher-res screen for VR. Still, all-in-all, and especially if I can resolve the freezing issue, this is the best phone imaginable, and its limitations are nothing compared to its heights. But yeah... at this point, wait for the next one if you're buying a phone now. Often my phone will unknowingly reboot in my pocket too. gizak No BT issues here either and I use BT in my car and headphones daily. As for your freezing, I experienced this too... after some extensive google searching, I narrowed it down to an app or two causing it. Mainly, any older app that uses your GPS periodically to poll for your location. Check apps that use GPS and haven't been updated since the latest version of Android, they may still be accessing the GPS directly instead of asking the android system for location (the newer more efficient way). IMO the top bezel on the nexus 5 was perfect size JR I'd have no problem recommending either of the Pixel devices to potential buyers, today. Many buyers enter the market for a new phone, because they need one. If you're one of those people who only updates their device when the current one is on its last leg, then the Pixel is an outstanding option (six months isn't something many would care to wait). The casual buyer primarily needs a good experience, preferably over a long term, and as discussed in this article, the Pixel delivers this quite well, 'right now' (to be fair, that's *if* you can find one). If the price drops once the Pixel 2 launches, even better. If you're talking to enthusiasts, then we can push this a few ways, but we always have the option to sell the Pixel, should we desire the new shiny thing. The Nexus 6P (still a great phone) fetches nice prices in the aftermarket, and the Pixel is generally understood to be an even better phone. I'm sure the Pixel will command a fine (but lower than new) aftermarket price, and there will always be a set of buyers who can't afford the absolute latest, but will be willing to scoop one up at a more realistic discount. So unless the device is missing game-breaking, hard features you rely on (waterproofing, because you're a part-time lifeguard), then I think it would be acceptable to recommend it. Google Maps gains Street View images for directions and a bottom bar for location info, directions, and more Cody Toombs Follow View All Posts 2017/05/12 6:03am PDTMay 12, 2017 30 Plus 1 on G+ 49 Share on Facebook 49 Share on Twitter Total Shares128 Applications Downloads News Videos Go check out the Google Maps app and you might notice a few things have changed since the last time you poked around. In the last couple of days, Google pushed some changes to the Maps interface that add street view images to the directions screen. It seems there's also another change showing up on more recent versions that will also move around a few widgets on the screen. When you begin planning a route between two places, the directions screen will now show thumbnails from Street View with every turn in the list Tapping on the image will open up Street View's full 360-degree viewer and direct it to the location of the turn. In the couple of tests I've done with it, Street View seems to also be oriented correctly for the view you'll have as you are driving â€“ meaning it won't point you at the wrong side of the road. As a bit of trivia, Google first introduced this feature to the Maps web interface right around this time of year back in 2008. There's even a video introducing it. Left: Older example. Right: New example. The other notable change is more widespread throughout the interface, but it's a mostly cosmetic adjustment. Many screens now include a bottom bar with contextual activities, often accompanied by a button on the right side. It takes up more space, but it functionally replaces the FAB (Floating Action Button) on many screens, or at least one of the FABs. This design may remove some confusion for users that don't immediately recognize the icons, but it may take a little longer since some users will have to read more. This is probably an experiment, but Google may eventually add this type of bottom bar to the Material Design Guidelines. These changes appear to have been activated remotely, so it's possible some users saw these much earlier as part of a test, while others may still see the older interface for a while. Street View thumbnails are showing up on versions of Maps going back at least as far as v9.51.1, the bottom bar seems to be limited to v9.52.0 and later. If you would like to get the very latest release before Google rolls it out to everybody, hit the APK Mirror link below. Download The APK is signed by Google and upgrades your existing app. The cryptographic signature guarantees that the file is safe to install and was not tampered with in any way. Rather than wait for Google to push this download to your devices, which can take days, download and install it just like any other APK. Version: 9.52.2 APK Mirror Download QR-Code Maps - Navigation & Transit Developer: Google Inc. Price: Free Thanks: Moshe and Eduardo Ribeiro Tags apk apk download app download downloads fab google maps maps material design street view video subscribe ... Edition: Global Â  One News Page â€œProbably the fastest-access news portal in the worldâ€ HOME WORLD SPORTS POLITICS BUSINESS PEOPLE SCITECH Science Â â€¢Â TechnologyÂ â€¢Â  ComputerÂ Industry Internet Automotive One News Page > Technology > Google Introduces Project Treble, a Modular Base for Android Google Introduces Project Treble, a Modular Base for Android Saturday, 13 May 2017Â (23 hours ago) Google has just announced a new project that the company has been working on, one that would make it easier for Android-running smartphones to be updated to the latest version. Project Treble will arrive on smartphones running Android O and beyond. Google stated that the process of updating an Android smartphone to the latest version is time consuming and costly for smartphone makers, which is why the market is so fragmented. The tech giantâ€™s attempt at solving this is Project Treble, which Google says itâ€™s â€œthe biggest change to the low-level system architecture of Android to date.â€ The life of an Android release requires multiple steps that must be fulfilled. Firstly, the Android team publishes the open-source code for the latest release. Then, chip manufacturers make modifications to the release to fit their specific hardware, and pass the modified version ... Social Media Enterprise Cybersecurity Tech Guide What your wife says about you on social media may not be what she thinks, ex-Googler warns People tell things to Google that they may not tell anyone else, Seth Stephens-Davidowitz says. For example, wives on social media could call their husbands "amazing" or "the best." On Google, "a jerk" or "annoying." Stephens-Davidowitz spent five years studying aggregate Google search data. Berkeley Lovelace Jr. | @BerkeleyJr 12 Hours AgoCNBC.com SHARES show chapters What your Google searches says about you: AuthorÂ Â Â  Friday, 12 May 2017 | 6:51 AM ET | 03:40 Want to really get to know someone? Well, you may not find the real answers on their social media accounts, ex-Google data scientist Seth Stephens-Davidowitz told CNBC on Friday. In an interview on "Squawk Box," Stephens-Davidowitz, who left Google after spending the last five years studying aggregate search data, said people search Google for things they might not divulge to anyone else. "People are constantly lying. They lie to friends, family members, to surveys, to social media, even to themselves. But they tend to be really honest with Google," said Stephens-Davidowitz, author of "Everybody Lies: Big Data, New Data, and What the Internet Reveals About Who We Really Are." Stephens-Davidowitz, who calls Google "digital truth serum," said people's search histories reveal some pretty bizarre and disturbing things. He said people living in areas you wouldn't expect to have high levels of racism often search for racist content. People also search about anxieties and insecurities that they wouldn't post about in real life or on social media. In the book, Stephens-Davidowitz said sometimes the findings are amusing. For example, wives on social media may call their husbands "amazing," "the best" or "so cute." On Google, however, they might search "a jerk" or "annoying." The data from Google could present a potential gold mine for marketers and business leaders who rely on using real data from people. Stephens-Davidowitz recommends those businesses use Google Trends, which he says is an underused source. Stephens-Davidowitz said all the data researched is anonymous and is pretty safe from a privacy perspective. But he warned about hacks to personal accounts that could reveal such data. "If someone hacked my account, I'm screwed. We're all screwed," he said. Berkeley Lovelace Jr.News Associate To view this site, you need to have JavaScript enabled in your browser, and either the Flash Plugin or an HTML5-Video enabled browser. A New Google Pixel Phone To Feature Android O, Hereâ€™s What We Know So Far. May 13, 2017 by Staff Â  Filed under Opinion, Tech/Internet, Weekly Columns 1 Comment Like Like Love Haha Wow Sad Angry 1 Tweet (ThyBlackMan.com)Â Talks about a new Google Pixel phone are at peak, as the Google I/O 2017 conference is just around the corner. The three-day event is scheduled to begin on May 17 and Google Pixel 2 or Google Pixel Taimen along with the two new Pixel phones is expected to be unveiled sometime soon. There are chances that the company will at least unveil Android O features and release date during the event as the new device is said to run on Android O operating system. The good thing is that a new Pixel phone details just appeared in a database of Geekbench, a popular mobile benchmarking app. According to the available details, the new Google Pixel phone named Google Taimen will run on Android O. The new version of the Android OS has already been announced, and it is also available for developer preview. Just like the last yearâ€™s Android N, the unnamed Android O is expected to be launched sometime in late summer or October. If the leaked details are something to go by, the new Pixel phone will come equipped with Snapdragon 835 octa-core processor. As usual, Google has codenamed the new phones, and it appears that the company will release three phones this year. Other than Google Taimen, the two phones include Muskie and Walleye. While there is no information provided by Google at this point, if both HTC and Google design new models keeping the issues from the previous releases, and inspirations from the latest hardware upgrades in mind, we will have some excellent smartphones from Google this year. So should you expect what is being circulated on the internet? Well, you should not. The specifications available on the website suggest that the new Google Pixel phone gives a score of 1804 in single core and 6248 in multi core. On the other hand, if you look at the Samsung Galaxy S8+, the test scores are 1929 and 6084 respectively. So it is very clear that if this is what Google is planning to bring with Taimen, it wonâ€™t stand against the rivals in smartphone market. The phone will not even compete well with OnePlus 5â€™s leaked scores of 1963 and 6687. Since Google hasnâ€™t confirmed whether these three devices will be beating the upcoming smartphones from the companies like Samsung and One Plus or not, nothing can be said at this point of time. There are chances that the numbers are probably the test scores when the device is running on a mid-level processor. Earlier this year, many reports claimed that the new Pixel phone will be powered by Snapdragon 653 chipset, which is a mid-range processor. So given this, there are chances that there will be a mid-range variant of the phone. There is one more thing which you should not ignore. The tests were probably taken and the scores we see represent the lowest possible clock speed. So, if this is the case then Googleâ€™s Pixel phone will definitely wonâ€™t disappoint users in terms of performance. Either way, the announcement of the upcoming Google Pixel phone is still far away. Since the company hasnâ€™t shared anything specific about its lineup of smartphones in the Pixel phone series, taking the leaked details with a pinch of salt is probably the best way. If you look at the last yearâ€™s Pixel phone, it was undoubtedly a groundbreaking device with beautiful design and powerful performance. With the 5-inch HD AMOLED screen, a 12.3 MP rear camera and an 8 MP front camera, the Google Pixel phone was and still is a complete package for smartphone enthusiasts. It would be really interesting to see how far Google will go in terms of user-friendly design, performance and software with its upcoming phones. Staff Writer; Corey Shaw Have any Tech Tips? News? Tip Us Android Police New Articles News Latest news Android O Nougat 7.0/7.1 Android OS Wearables Android TV Android Auto Development More News... Apps/Games Games Applications Roundups App Reviews Game Reviews More Apps/Games... Reviews All reviews Phone Reviews Tablet Reviews Wearable Reviews Other Reviews More Reviews... Devices Nexus Devices Samsung HTC Motorola Sony LG NVIDIA Huawei More Devices... Leaks Exclusives Downloads Deals Giveaways Features Editorials Tip Us Prev Posts in the last 24 Hours 24 Hours 48 Hours 72 Hours sorted by Hottest Hottest Latest Comments Next Leaks Exclusives Downloads Deals Giveaways Features Editorials Tip Us ... Google's "Project Treble" will modularize Android to make updates faster Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/05/12 12:42pm PDTMay 12, 2017 95 Plus 1 on G+ 162 Share on Facebook 76 Share on Twitter Total Shares333 Android O Android OS Development Google News Easily the most annoying aspect of using an Android phone (with the exception of Pixel/Nexus) is slow updates. Android 7.1 (which came out last year) currently sits at 0.5% marketshare, and brand new phones are still being released with 6.0 Marshmallow.Â Google is aiming to solve this with "Project Treble," which will modularize part of the Android OS to decrease the time OEMs spend updating their devices. If you're not familiar with how Android updates work, here's a summary. Google releases a new Android version, which silicon manufacturers (e.g. Qualcomm, Mediatek) have to supply drivers for. Once that's done, device makers (e.g. Samsung, HTC) can start re-adding all the tweaks they have made to the new Android source code. In the case of carrier-sold phones/tablets, device makers then have to wait for the carriers to approve the update. After all that is done, users finally start to receive the update. Google is hoping to speed up this process with Project Treble, which changes the architecture of Android. Essentially, a new 'Vendor interface' will contain all of the low-level software for a device - like the chipset drivers. Google will work with chipset manufacturers to make sure the Vendor interface is forwards-compatible, and the interface will be validated by a Vendor Test Suite (VTS). The aspect of this news I'm most excited about is that the Vendor interface is forwards-compatible.Â There have been many cases where chipset manufacturers have not updated drivers for specific popular chips, preventing devices using them from being officially updated to newer Android versions. One example is the Nexus 5 and other Snapdragon 800/801-based devices, which were never officially updated to 7.0 Nougat. It sounds like the Vendor interface will prevent this from happening, or at least prolongÂ the end of support for a given chip. Google says that Android O will be the first version to use the new Vendor interface, and the Android O Developer Preview already has it. Hopefully we'll hear more about Project Treble at Google I/O next week. Source: Android Developers Tags Android android o project treble treble vendor interface vendor test suite vts subscribe ... CA-Sandra Fuchsia is a very long term project. It's not going to replace Android anytime soon. Dextro I've been saying for ages that Android needs an hardware abstraction in the vein of what Windows has in its driver model. Hopefully this is it and helps get those updates out faster. Sadly I expect that the endless stream of UI customization OEM make will end up killing any kind of benefit this brings. Corbin Davenport I want something like that too, but I'm not deeply familiar with the technical structure of Linux/Android, so I would assume sure there some massive limitation that is keeping that from happening. Dextro I think (but am now 100% sure on this so don't quote me) that Linux historically hasn't had any such abstraction. Drivers are meant to be inside the kernel and compiled for each specific version. That works fine if the code is open source and committed to the kernel repos but it becomes a nightmare for binary blobs. The kernel makes no allowances for stable driver APIs, they will break stuff and won't worry for anything outside of the kernel if I remember correctly. That's probably part of the reason why Android has failed to keep up with Linux kernel versions. keithzg The kernel makes no allowances for stable driver APIs, they will break stuff and won't worry for anything outside of the kernel if I remember correctly. I wouldn't really say this is true. In fact, there is a very stable API provided by the Linux kernel. Hell, one of the most famous Linus rants was about this very topic: It's a bug alright - in the kernel. How long have you been a maintainer? And you *still* haven't learnt the first rule of kernel maintenance? If a change results in user programs breaking, it's a bug in the kernel. We never EVER blame the user programs. How hard can this be to understand? WE DO NOT BREAK USERSPACE! https://lkml.org/lkml/2012/12/23/75 Obviously drivers are trickier, but they're still expected to continue working. The big catch comes in that ARM drivers tend to come as compiled binary blobs. There really isn't an allowance for that in the workflow of things for Linux; good citizens are supposed to provide source, and then new kernel versions and the drivers therefore (often within the kernel itself) are recompiled, and everyone's happy. But while the API remains the same, the ABI does not; drivers compiled as modules for an older kernel won't work on newer ones, even though the drivers would almost certainly work fine if they were recompiled. The ARM space is utterly lousy with proprietary drivers (in no small part this is Qualcomm's fault, although they're far from the only offender). Hence you have Google forever backporting kernel updates to older kernels, so that the ABI remains consistent and older device drivers continue working. Dextro Well, I stand corrected then. But one question then: I was under the impression that drivers were not in userspace but in kernelspace. That's why I didn't even think much of that famous Linus rant. keithzg True, they're (generally; FUSE, for instance, is an area of exception) in kernel space, and that rant isn't entirely applicable because of that, but for practical purposes that just means ABI changes break drivers. And the kernel devs do reserve the right to change the in-kernel API at any point, which could in theory break drivers---it's just that in practice they are rather worried about such breakage and don't wish to do so, and barely break it more than they do userspace. When you think about it, it'd kindof be an insane amount of maintenance if people had to update driver code for new kernel versions! Luckily for "desktop Linux", most drivers these days in the x86 space are open source (NVIDIA is remaining holdout, although even there you can fall back to the Nouveau drivers most of the time), so they're just baked into the kernel or provided as kernel modules, and in practice don't really have to be touched by human hands after they're originally written. Unluckily for Android, that is very much not true in the ARM hardware world. Hell, most Chinese OEMs will just flatly refuse to provide kernel source, even though they're legally obligated to do so. Gaurav Kumar Which is why fuchsia has a stable ABI...like windows. I agree it's not coming anytime soon but it may not be that far away as well.. Lawstorant in the linux world, the answer is DKMS. There's no need for kernel catch-up anymore. I bet Google is doing something similar. Ð¡ÐµÑ€Ð³ÐµÐ¹ Ð‘ÑƒÐ³Ð°ÐµÐ² Android has the HAL https://source.android.com/devices/#Hardware-Abstraction-Layer -- but it haven't been helping much, as we can see (or would it be much worse without it?). Andy J https://developer.android.com/things/index.html pretty much this is what they are aiming for - from the days of Project Brillo. "System updates and support: We provide the system image, updates, fixes, and more, so you can focus on creating compelling products" Brillo/Things is the same idea - there is the low level vendor stuff, the actual OS and then the OEM stuff. Google can update the OS on running devices in the field, without worrying about the vendor stuff or the OEM stuff. Knowledgeborn Allah Exactly... In just a few years, well-mannered self-driving robotaxis will share the roads with reckless, law-breaking human drivers. The prospect is causing migraines for the people developing the robocars and is slowing their development. But experts say eventually the cars will coexist with human drivers on real roads. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg, File) Gene J. Puskar FILE - In this Wednesday, Sept. 14, 2016, file photo, a self-driving Uber car stops at a red light on Liberty Avenue through the Bloomfield neighborhood of Pittsburgh. In just a few years, well-mannered self-driving robotaxis will share the roads with reckless, law-breaking human drivers. The prospect is causing migraines for the people developing the robocars and is slowing their development. But experts say eventually the cars will coexist with human drivers on real roads. (AP Photo/Gene J. Puskar, File) AP Criminal allegations, legal and image woes mount for Uber By TOM KRISHER and MICHAEL LIEDTKE AP Business Writers May 12, 2017 Updated 20 hrs ago (â€¦) Eric Risberg FILE - In this Tuesday, Dec. 13, 2016, file photo, an Uber driverless car waits in traffic during a test drive in San Francisco. In just a few years, well-mannered self-driving robotaxis will share the roads with reckless, law-breaking human drivers. The prospect is causing migraines for the people developing the robocars and is slowing their development. But experts say eventually the cars will coexist with human drivers on real roads. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg, File) Gene J. Puskar FILE - In this Wednesday, Sept. 14, 2016, file photo, a self-driving Uber car stops at a red light on Liberty Avenue through the Bloomfield neighborhood of Pittsburgh. In just a few years, well-mannered self-driving robotaxis will share the roads with reckless, law-breaking human drivers. The prospect is causing migraines for the people developing the robocars and is slowing their development. But experts say eventually the cars will coexist with human drivers on real roads. (AP Photo/Gene J. Puskar, File) SAN FRANCISCO (AP) â€” A rare order from a federal judge alerting prosecutors to possible criminal misconduct by Uber or a key executive deepens the turmoil swirling around the ride-hailing company at a time when it's grappling with other legal and image problems. District Judge William Alsup in San Francisco referred a civil case filed against Uber by Waymo to the U.S. Attorney's Office "for investigation of possible theft of trade secrets." It threatens to trigger a second U.S. government investigation of a company that has pushed the legal boundaries through most of its eight-year history. At stake is Uber's estimated $68 billion valuation, a possible public stock offering and the future of its self-driving car program, which its CEO has said is the key to the company's future. Story continues below video Ã— Advertisement Waymo, a self-driving car company owned by Google parent Alphabet Inc., sued Uber in February alleging that Uber is using stolen self-driving technology to build its own fleet of autonomous cars. The U.S. Attorney's Office in San Francisco didn't respond to requests for comment. Experts say prosecutors are likely to follow up on Alsup's order and launch an investigation. The probe, combined with other legal and image woes, will reduce Uber's value and in the worst case could threaten the San Francisco company's existence if investors leave, criminal charges bring huge fines and legal action stalls autonomous car research, the experts say. Uber wouldn't comment Friday on a possible criminal probe. Federal prosecutors already have requested information from at least two cities about use of phony software to thwart city officials looking at whether Uber was following local regulations. Alsup wrote in his order that he wasn't taking a position on whether prosecution was warranted. Alsup, 71, has gained a reputation as a no-nonsense judge since he was appointed to the bench in 1999 by President Bill Clinton. The Harvard Law graduate has experience in trials involving high-profile technology companies, including a 2012 patent and copyright infringement case pitting Oracle against Google. For a judge to take such a public step, he must have more than just a whiff of criminal activity, legal experts say. Prosecutors get many tips, but rarely do they come from a judge who is familiar with evidence and the legal elements of what is a crime. "This is not some private informant that slipped an envelope under the door at midnight. This is public and it's a judge," said Erik Gordon, a law and business professor at the University of Michigan. An investigation would siphon executive resources at Uber just as CEO Travis Kalanick faces many other challenges, said John Coffee, a Columbia University law professor who specializes in white-collar crime and corporate governance. "The possibility that you could get criminally indicted would be exactly the wrong thing for Uber," Coffee said. In addition to the apparent inquiry into the software called "Greyball" to impede city inspectors, Uber still has to deal with Waymo's high-stakes espionage lawsuit. It alleges that Uber is using trade secrets stolen by a former Google engineer, Anthony Levandowski, who formed his own company which was bought by Uber $680 million. After that deal, Levandowski began to oversee Uber's self-driving car division. Waymo contends that before leaving Google early last year, Levandowski downloaded 14,000 documents with details of a navigational tool called Lidar that robotic cars need to see what's around them. Uber has vehemently denied using Waymo's ideas, maintaining that its Lidar is radically different. Meanwhile, Levandowski has refused to answer most questions posed by Waymo's lawyers while asserting his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. He recently agreed to step down as Uber's top self-driving car executive, though he still works at the company. Beyond the possible criminal cases, Kalanick in February was forced to quit President Donald Trump's council of business leaders after Uber was boycotted by some customers. A female former engineer made a series of sexual harassment allegations about her boss, and a video of Kalanick berating an Uber driver went viral, forcing him to concede he needs leadership help. Earlier this week, Uber suffered a huge legal setback when a European Union judge ruled that it was a transport company and could be required to get licenses and permits in the 28 EU nations. Uber had sought to persuade Alsup to send the dispute between Waymo and Levandowski to private arbitration hearings. But the judge rejected that request, meaning the case will play out in a public court, risking further image damage for Uber. Just months ago Uber was discussing what could have been the largest public stock offering in history, but its troubles now make that all but impossible, Gordon said. Uber can survive the troubles, but it has an uphill fight, said Gordon. If the court finds that Uber used Google's Lidar technology, that will slow Uber's autonomous car research, leaving it behind competitors. The company would either have to pay Alphabet to use it or buy it from a supplier, both expensive options, Gordon said. The company's strategy of fostering rapid growth by flouting laws may wind up being its undoing, Gordon said. "The empire is striking back." ____ Krisher reported from Detroit. Copyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. Hereâ€™s how to evade the snoopers Photograph: Shutterstock/Bryan Mayes Internet The Observer How to escape the online spies Whether youâ€™re tweeting, shopping or just browsing, internet companies are monitoring you. Hereâ€™s how to evade the snoopers Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share via Email View more sharing options Share on LinkedIn Share on Pinterest Share on Google+ Share on WhatsApp Share on Messenger Close Darien Graham-Smith @DarienGS Saturday 13 May 2017 14.00Â EDT Last modified on Saturday 13 May 2017 19.10Â EDT Nobody likes being spied on. When youâ€™re innocently browsing the web, itâ€™s deeply unpleasant to think that faceless technology corporations are monitoring and recording your every move. While such data collection is legal, that doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s all right. There are plenty of things you might prefer to keep to yourself, such as your income, your sexuality, your political views or your membership of the Yoko Ono fanclub. For an indication of what can be inferred from your online habits, take a look at the Apply Magic Sauce tool produced by Cambridge Psychometrics Centre, which produces a profile of your personality based on Facebook and Twitter data. And while you might console yourself with the knowledge that all of this information is mostly used for targeting ads, that might not be the case for much longer. The internet giants are building up ever more detailed user profiles â€“ and finding new ways to exploit that information. In the Observer, Carole Cadwalladrâ€™s ongoing investigation has highlighted how analytic techniques were used in the recent EU referendum to target and craft messages to groups of persuadable voters based on psychological insights gleaned from online data. Even if you are relaxed about analytics companies gaming the political process, you may be more bothered about the effect on your wallet: researchers at the Polytechnic University of Catalonia have already found evidence that some online retailers use profiling to discriminate against certain customers. If youâ€™re identified as a high-value shopper, youâ€™re likely to be steered towards more expensive products, or even charged more than other visitors for the same item. And thatâ€™s just the start of it. Experts warn that, in the future, your online activity could be taken into consideration when you apply for a loan â€“ or for a job. Thatâ€™s troubling, not least because profiling involves a large element of assumption and inference. Something as innocent as searching for a medical condition â€“ even out of mere curiosity â€“ could cause your insurance premiums to rocket, and youâ€™ll never know why. Even if youâ€™ve nothing to hide, therefore, it may be wise to minimise your exposure to online tracking. Hereâ€™s how some of the biggest names on the web spy on you â€“ and how to protect your privacy. Amazon Facebook Twitter Pinterest Pressing the mute button on top of Amazonâ€™s Echo voice assistant will temporarily stop it from recording audio. Photograph: Samuel Gibbs for the Guardian Amazon has a disconcerting habit of following you around the web. Spend a few minutes browsing its catalogue for a new crepe pan, and you might find that the next site you visit is mysteriously festooned with ads for cookware. Thankfully, Amazon gives you an easy way to opt out of being tracked in this way. Simply click on â€œYour Accountâ€ from the Amazon homepage, then scroll down to â€œAdvertising Preferencesâ€: here youâ€™ll see the option to disable personalised ads. Note that since this feature relies on cookies, it will only take effect in the browser youâ€™re currently using. Under â€œAdvertising Preferencesâ€, youâ€™ll also see the option to view and manage your browsing history; from here you can disable tracking altogether, or remove individual items from your Amazon history. That could be useful if youâ€™re shopping for a gift, or if youâ€™ve been browsing unfashionable items youâ€™d rather not be reminded of. What about Amazonâ€™s voice assistant devices? If youâ€™ve got an Amazon Echo in your home, you might be concerned about it listening in on private conversations. Rest assured, the Echo doesnâ€™t record anything it hears until you address it with the appropriate â€œwake wordâ€ (normally â€œAlexaâ€). Whatever you say next is relayed to Amazon, where itâ€™s processed and stored, but you can wipe this data at any time â€“ youâ€™ll find the option to do so in Amazonâ€™s â€œManage Your Content and Devicesâ€ settings. To ensure that Alexa canâ€™t be woken up even by accident, you can also press the mute button on the top of the Echo to temporarily disable the microphone; just press it again to turn it back on. Itâ€™s worth noting, however, that the Echoâ€™s software updates automatically, so its behaviour could change at any time. Weâ€™ll be keeping a sharp eye out for any updates that could compromise your privacy. Apple Facebook Twitter Pinterest The macOS operating system passes your search terms on to Apple. Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian iPhones and iPads collect a lot of data about you, and itâ€™s accessible not just to Apple but to third-party apps too. The â€œPrivacyâ€ section in the iOS Settings app gives you an overview of whatâ€™s being collected, and lets you disable various data-sharing features. One particular thing to note is that if youâ€™re carrying an iPhone around in your pocket, it will be constantly keeping track of your location, and potentially sharing it. You can easily tell it not to, though: in the Settings app, tap on â€œPrivacyâ€ > â€œLocation Servicesâ€ and select which apps should have access to your GPS data. You can also disable system services such as â€œFrequent Locationsâ€, or disable location services altogether â€“ though this means that apps like Apple Maps wonâ€™t work. Itâ€™s a similar situation for Mac users. The macOS system uses network connections to work out where in the world your computer is located, and this information can be shared with applications and websites. You can manage this from â€œSystem Preferencesâ€ > â€œSecurity & Privacyâ€. Another privacy concern for macOS users is the fact that every time you search for something in Spotlight, your search terms are passed on to Apple, so the companyâ€™s servers can provide suggested links to online sources. You can disable this feature by opening â€œSystem Preferencesâ€ > â€œSpotlightâ€ and unticking the box for â€œSpotlight Suggestionsâ€. Finally, keep an eye on your webcam, as malware can allow hackers to literally spy on you via your Macâ€™s built-in camera. If the light comes on unexpectedly, that means someoneâ€™s watching you; for complete peace of mind, you can always cover the camera with opaque tape. Consider also going to â€œSystem Preferencesâ€ > â€œSoundâ€ and disabling the internal microphone, to ensure no oneâ€™s eavesdropping on your conversations. Facebook Facebook Twitter Pinterest Facebook: you might decide the safest option is not to have an account. Photograph: Carl Court/Getty Images Youâ€™ve probably handed plenty of personal information to Facebook yourself â€“ but the social network also tracks your visits to other websites to build up a scarily detailed profile of your lifestyle and interests. This information is mostly used for targeting ads, but it could be turned to other purposes in the future. Facebook is quite open about the information it collects. When you see an ad on your timeline, you can always click the drop-down menu at its top right and select â€œWhy am I seeing this?â€ to discover why Facebook chose to show you an ad for a smartphone, rather than one for scented soap. For a fuller explanation of what Facebook knows about you, go to the â€œSettingsâ€ page and click â€œAdvertsâ€ to inspect your advertising profile. If there are any mistakes here, or advertisers you donâ€™t want to hear from, they can be removed or blocked with a click. The creepy part is that, by default, Facebookâ€™s targeted ads donâ€™t appear only in Facebook itself. Facebook uses cookies to follow your profile on to other websites and, like Amazon, ensure that you see the ads it wants you to. You can disable this behaviour from the advert preferences page: under â€œAdvert settingsâ€ youâ€™ll see a rather awkwardly phrased setting for â€œAds on apps and websites off of the Facebook Companiesâ€. Set this to â€œNoâ€ and you should regain a degree of online anonymity. Of course, this doesnâ€™t mean that Facebook isnâ€™t still profiling you: thereâ€™s sadly no easy way to stop it collecting information. Your best bet is to turn to the measures described in â€œThe internetâ€, below, such as enabling â€œDo Not Trackâ€ in your browser, specifically opting out or installing an anti-tracking browser extension. Or, of course, you may decide itâ€™s safest just to delete your Facebook account. Google Facebook Twitter Pinterest Googleâ€™s My Activity page allows you to view your entire browsing history. Photograph: Samuel Gibbs for the Guardian Most of us use Google services every day, and as a result the web giant knows a huge amount about our movements and interests. You can find out everything itâ€™s learned about you at myaccount.google.com. Your data is all set out in an impressively forthright way; the only problem is, thereâ€™s so much information to work through that it can be bewildering to navigate. One section thatâ€™s worth your attention is â€œManage your Google activityâ€. Here youâ€™ll find Googleâ€™s activity controls, which let you disable various types of data collection. For example, you can tell Google not to log your Chrome browsing history and activity, to stop tracking your location and to desist from keeping records of any voice commands you might issue. Turning these features off can make Google services less smart, but you might consider that a price worth paying. For a closer look at the information Googleâ€™s been collecting on you lately, click on â€œMy activityâ€. This brings up a timeline showing all of your searches, webpage visits, Android app activity and so forth. Seeing your digital life laid bare like this can be pretty unnerving: if thereâ€™s something youâ€™d prefer Google to forget, simply click on the menu icon to its right and delete. If you want to thoroughly inspect everything Google knows about you, you can even download a comprehensive archive of personal information by clicking on â€œControl your contentâ€ > â€œDownload your dataâ€. Be warned, though, this archive can be huge: the default settings include all the emails in your Gmail account, and any videos you may have uploaded to YouTube. If you want to limit the information you share with Google in the future, the easiest way is simply to use it less. For example, try the privacy-focused search engine at duckduckgo.com, and use an alternative browser such as Firefox. Microsoft Windows 10â€™s â€œtelemetryâ€ features automatically capture all sorts of information about what youâ€™re doing on your PC, and send it back to Microsoft. The company insists that this information is only used to improve Windows, but it can still feel like a violation. The recent â€œCreators Updateâ€ to Windows 10 prompts you to review your privacy settings as part of the update process, but you can check and change your settings at any time: simply open the Windows 10 Settings app and click on â€œPrivacyâ€. Youâ€™ll find no fewer than 18 pages of configuration options, covering everything from personalised advertising to location services. There are a few settings you might particularly want to check. One feature of Windows 10 that may be cause for concern is the way it tracks everything you type â€“ yes, everything â€“ and shares it with Microsoft. This is supposed to help the operating system learn the way you work, but if the idea makes you shudder, you can disable it under â€œSpeech, inking and typingâ€. Under â€œFeedback & diagnosticsâ€, meanwhile, you can choose how much diagnostic information gets periodically sent back to Microsoft. A full report includes details of which applications youâ€™ve been using and which websites youâ€™ve been visiting, so you might prefer to switch to the more limited basic setting. You can also manage the information that Microsoft already knows about you by visiting the Privacy Dashboard at account.microsoft.com/privacy. While not strictly a privacy issue, another controversial aspect of Windows 10 is the inclusion of ads in the user interface. To remove unwanted ads from the Start menu, go to â€œSettingsâ€ > â€œPersonalisationâ€ > â€œStartâ€ and disable â€œOccasionally show suggestions in Startâ€. To stop Microsoft advertising its OneDrive cloud storage service, open File Explorer, then select â€œViewâ€ > â€œOptionsâ€ > â€œChange folder and search optionsâ€, click on the â€œViewâ€ tab, and untick â€œShow sync provider notificationsâ€. The internet Facebook Twitter Pinterest Google Chrome, like most major browsers, has options to disable tracking. Photograph: Samuel Gibbs for the Guardian All right, itâ€™s an exaggeration to say that the internet as a whole is spying on you. But there are a hell of a lot of companies out there keeping tabs on your online activity. The motivation normally comes down to filthy lucre â€“ tracking your interests helps them push relevant ads your way, and to be fair you might prefer those to irrelevant ones. If youâ€™d rather not be tracked, one step you can immediately take is to enable the â€œdo not trackâ€ feature in your browser. Yes, itâ€™s that simple: every major web browser has the capability to tell websites that you donâ€™t want to be followed â€“ you can find more details at donottrack.us. The only problem with this system is that compliance is completely optional, so websites that want to follow you still can. Another thing you can do is visit youradchoices.com, a site that checks your browser for â€œtracking cookiesâ€ from more than 100 companies. You can disable individual cookies, or turn off all behavioural advertising with a single click. After this, youâ€™ll still see ads, but they wonâ€™t be customised to your interests any more. A more drastic solution is to configure your browser to reject third-party cookies â€“ that is, cookies that connect to a site other than the one youâ€™re currently browsing. However, this can cause problems if, for example, a site uses embedded content from elsewhere on the web. A safer option is to use a tool such as Ghostery ; this free browser extension can block tracking cookies from more than 4,500 companies, while letting you selectively enable cross-site content. Itâ€™s a pain that this should be necessary, but if you donâ€™t want your personal information to be shared around online, itâ€™s a precaution worth taking.
