My Profile My Subscriptions Log Out Newfoundland & Labrador LIVE St. John's More Streams CBC Radio One Listen Live CBC News Canada CBC News Navigation Home Opinion World Canada Politics Business Health Entertainment Technology & Science Video Canada NL Meet Catherine Courage, Newfoundlander in top ranks at Google 'Focused on people': Newfoundland roots an advantage for style of management Google looks for ByÂ Geoff Bartlett, CBC News Posted: May 13, 2017 2:56 PM NT Last Updated: May 13, 2017 2:56 PM NT Catherine Courage of St. John's is a senior vice-president at Google, one of the world's most successful companies. She's back in her hometown to give a presentation as part of Innovation Week. (Krissy Holmes/CBC) Related Stories Schools need better computer science education, group says External Links Innovation Week (Note: CBC does not endorse and is not responsible for the content of external links.) A St. John's woman is making a name for herself in California's Silicon Valley as an executive with Google. 'People who come there are very smart, engagedÂ and are there because they want to make an impact.' - Catherine Courage Catherine CourageÂ is the vice-president of ads and commerce user experience at the corporation, and in 2013 was namedÂ one of the top women of influence by the Silicon Valley Business Journal. She's back in her hometownÂ as a special guest speaker for Accelerating Innovation, a weeklong eventÂ where innovators, startups and other stakeholders share ideas on how to improve innovation in Newfoundland and Labrador. The Googleplex corporate headquarters complex of Google and its parent company Alphabet in Mountain View, Calif. (Wikipedia) Courage, who has a master's degree in applied sciences from the University of Toronto, said she applied for the job at GoogleÂ despite some worry that she was in over her head. "Sometimes you do have those moments of self-doubt," she told the St. John's Morning Show.Â "But when you feel that sense of doubt or fear, it's actually a good thing and you have to embrace it." As a woman working in an industry typically dominated by men, Courage attributes her success to having strong female figures in her life when she was growing up, such as her mother and three aunts, who were all highly educated and successful. Catherine Courage and others take part in a panel at the Sheraton Hotel in St. John's as part of Innovation Week 2017. (Twitter/@msimms28) Until recently, she neverÂ focused on the fact that she was a woman, but now that she's in a leadership position she feels more of a responsibility to encourage other young women to get involved in the tech industry. "I would absolutely encourage any young female to really explore the tech sector. It'sÂ a great career," she said.Â  "It's exciting.Â There are a lot of learning opportunities. Typically they have great benefits, compensation, and lots of flexibility for people who want to have families." Newfoundland values Courage said working for GoogleÂ is a challenging butÂ very rewarding experience, as the company gives their employees a great deal of flexibility when it comes to pursuing ideas. She said growing up in Newfoundland has given her an approach that progressive companies like Google deeply value. "When I think about being a Newfoundlander I think we're very human and I think we're very focused on people," she said. "That's really allowed me to excel as a good manager because I'm not just thinking about the tasks and the process and speed. I really try and think about the people I work with, and I think that goes a long way." Inside the Googleplex building. Catherine Courage says the company embraces an ethic of working hard and playing hard. She said her peers at GoogleÂ think of her home province as an "exotic" place that they've heard of throughÂ things like the Fogo Island Inn and the Come From Away musical. Work hard, play hard Despite what many people think, Courage said there's much more to working at a giant tech company than playing ping pong or working while sitting on beanbag chairs. "There is a lot of fun, I will say.Â They do a great job of taking care of their employees and making it a very fun and engaging environment," she said. "The flip side of thatÂ is a lot of hard work. People who come there are very smart, engagedÂ and they are there because they want to make an impact." If you own a Galaxy S7 or Galaxy S7 Edge, weâ€™ve put together a guide that will take you through the most important things to know about your update. If you own a Galaxy S6 or Galaxy Note 5, weâ€™ve put together guides that will take you through the most exciting things about their release. 3 Reasons Not to Install Galaxy S7 Nougat & 8 Reasons You Should Install Nougat If You Want Better Security Â  1 / 11 Let's start with some basics. If you value your security, and most of you probably do, you'll want toÂ think about installing the Galaxy S7 Nougat update soon after it arrives for your device.Â  Every month, Google and Samsung release important security patches for Android devices. The Galaxy S7 and Galaxy S7Â Android Nougat updates should bring the latest security patches to your device. Samsung's initial batch of Galaxy S7 Nougat updatesÂ delivered the company's January security updateÂ while upcoming updates could deliver the patches from the February securityÂ update.Â You can read more about their contents on Samsung's website.Â  If you failed to download or receive an olderÂ security update (December, November, etc), the patches from those updates mightÂ be baked into your version of Nougat. If not, youÂ might be forced to install them manually before you can download Nougat.Â  On top of the patches, Samsung's Galaxy S7 Nougat update brings Samsung Pass, aÂ way to secureÂ your identity using biometric data rather than entering your password or ID.Â  Samsung Pass is like a master key for your various logins and it relies on Galaxy S7's fingerprint scanner. The biometric data is encrypted and stored safelyÂ by Samsung Knox. gizmodo Deadspin Fusion Gizmodo Jalopnik Jezebel Kotaku Lifehacker The Root Video Sploid Paleofuture io9 Science Reviews Field Guide Microsoft's Apps Problem Has Never Been More Dire Alex CranzYesterday 12:57pm Filed to: Microsoft Build 2017 Build Microsoft Windows 10 Windows Store Windows 10 S 105 4 Edit Promote Share to Kinja Toggle Conversation tools Go to permalink Images: Alex Cranz/Gizmodo At Microsoftâ€™s Build conference, the dorkiest of companies put on a big show, complete with fog machines and fancy lights, in order to show itâ€™s a cool competitor to Apple and Google. The speakers who came on stage during keynotes had stylish hair. â€œDo they have dressers backstage?â€ an attendee asked a group of us when it was all over. Advertisement Build exists to get developers excited. The biggest devs blow upwards of $2000 for a three-day pass to the event, where they have unlimited drinks, plentiful meals, and access to Microsoftâ€™s best and brightest. Part of Microsoftâ€™s wooing process involves appearing â€œhipâ€ to a group of developers who resemble the cast of Silicon Valley in all the worst ways. Hence the light show and Microsoft EVP Terry Myersonâ€™s questionable hoodie and leather vest combo. It wants these devs so amped that theyâ€™ll rush back to their MacBook Airs and Surface Books to crank out brilliant software, hopefully for Microsoftâ€™s Windows Store, which has just one third of the apps of much cooler stores from Google and Apple. With the arrival of Windows 10 S, which can only use apps from the Windows Store, the app marketplace has never been more important than today. Yet time after time over the course of the event, Microsoft dropped the ball on its pitch to developers in favor of niche distractions. Appleâ€™s a monolith of money and users, and thanks to Android and Chrome OS, Google is right there with it. Both have OS platforms with heavily used app stores. Theyâ€™ve built customer bases of hungry fans that enthusiastically embrace their hardware and software products, and consequently, developers want to build apps that work with Apple and Google platforms. Microsoft, on the other hand, canâ€™t seem to ditch the buttoned-up association itâ€™s developed for making the work computer you donâ€™t want to use. Its reputation is seemingly forever cemented by those old Mac vs PC commercials. Attempts to rewrite the script have been met with mixed success. On the hardware side, Microsoft has become a genuine player in the field of coveted kit. The Surface Pro and Studio are ambitious devices that are legitimately exciting. The Surface Laptop announced earlier this month is one of the most interesting products announced so far this year. But Microsoftâ€™s software landscape is still dorktown and one of the big ways Microsoftâ€™s attempting to undorkify things is by leaning into the Windows Store. Thereâ€™s a problem though. Microsoftâ€™s app store in uncommonly small compared to the other guys. According to Microsoft, in 2015 there were just 669,000 apps available. (The company hasnâ€™t officially updated that number since.) According to Statista Apple and Google both have more than three times that number of apps available in their stores. Advertisement Advertisement The number of available apps alone doesnâ€™t necessarily dictate the quality of someoneâ€™s computing experience, but it remains a common metric for success, and if Microsoft wants to look cooler in the software space, it needs a big awesome app store full of big awesome apps. Microsoft stunned the audience of Build when it announced iTunes was coming to the store just a week after announcing Spotifyâ€™s arrival. Those are two hugely important apps, and you could feel the energy in the keynote after the announcement. Developers and press looked at one another, baffled and delighted. An Apple app would appear in the Windows Store! Then Microsoft immediately squandered that excitement. The rest of the focus both on stage and later in the â€œHub,â€ the primary showroom for the conference, wasnâ€™t on the cool apps traditional users might want, but on the deeply nerdy niche stuff. Sponsored During the keynote itself, Microsoft glossed over the lifestyle apps to focus on Autodesk and Linux. Autodesk was up on stage to announce that Autodesk Stingray was headed to the store. Stingray is an engine used to build things in 3D and is almost exclusively used by 3D artists and engineers. After that announcement, Microsoft followed up with the news that Linux was coming to the store. If youâ€™re excited about the Linux distributions Ubuntu, Suse, and Fedora arriving to the Windows Store, know youâ€™re uncommon. Itâ€™s big news for developers, but meaningless to people who would normally seek out apps on an app store in the first place. Site of the Build keynote. There are lots of blue lights and...fog? Given Microsoftâ€™s enthusiasm for the store, it was weird that the companyâ€™s newly announced operating system, Windows 10 S, which can only get apps through the store, was mostly absent from the conference, apart from a few mentions during the keynote. You couldnâ€™t find it anywhere on the show floor, where developers mingle with Microsoft personnel. Nerd city. The Store booth had a lone TV screen with a rep standing in front of itâ€”and that rep had not been briefed on Windows 10 S. In fact, it seemed no one had. Every Microsoft rep I asked seemed bewildered by Windows 10 S questions. They could say it was â€œexcitingâ€ but they had no spiel ready for why it was exciting, nor why the Store was crucial to its success. Advertisement And no one could explain what, fundamentally, might have changed about the Windows Store to make it an appealing avenue for app launches after a five years of sluggish adoption. Even app developers that were bullish about the platform were frustratingly vague about what was different now compared to when the Store launched in 2012, and why Windows 10 S would not go the way of its failed store-focused predecessors Windows RT and Windows 8.1 with Bing. Christoph Teschner and Michael Simmons were positively giddy about Windows 10 S when I sat down with them in a high-rise hotel near the conference. Both men are employees of Algoriddim, and were in Seattle because their app, DJay Pro, had just received the App Creator of the Year award. â€œI think thatâ€™s the future,â€ Simmons said of the Windows App store. Advertisement Teschner pointed to his own youth, growing up with Appleâ€™s app stores for Mac and iOS and how it had prepared him for the Windows Store. â€œPeople are used to app stores now,â€ he said. â€œIt felt sort of natural to me when I first got my Windows Store.â€ Though they were reluctant to give exact numbers or concrete evidence of a successful Windows Store launch, Simmons said â€œWindows fulfilled our expectations.â€ He praised the development process in particular. â€œSeeing developer tools ten years ago, itâ€™s a total leap today. Itâ€™s an evolution and weâ€™re in the middle of it.â€ Neither man could give a concrete reason for why they felt Windows 10 S had a chance to succeed when its predecessors failed so badly, but sitting in a room and soaking up their optimism it was hard not to be swayed a little. Advertisement Advertisement And itâ€™s that kind of optimism for app developers that Microsoft will need if it hopes to actually fill the Store with cool apps. If those men had been on the show floor, showing off their app and talking up their own experiences with developing for the store, Build might have actually projected the image Microsoft desperately needs. But Microsoft is still figuring it out. It has ditched the pocket protector, but itâ€™s still not cool. Recommended Stories What Is Microsoft's Grand Plan for Phones? Add groups with QR Codes Google is also trying to make Allo easier to use, and for that theyâ€™ve launchedÂ QR Codes for groups. With these new codes, friends can just scan your code and theyâ€™ll join your conversation. Even better: In case the link goes online for some reason, you can reset it. In that case, the first link wonâ€™t work anymore, and youâ€™ll get a new link. Â  Google Assistant Settings Since Google Assistant came out, all settings were only in the Google App. Google is now preparing Google Assistant settings inside Allo. <string name=â€google_assistant_settingsâ€>Assistant Settings</string> <string name=â€assistant_all_options_subtitleâ€>Update what the Assistant knows about you</string> <string name=â€assistant_all_options_titleâ€>Assistant options</string> We donâ€™t have much more information about this for now, but as you can see above, youâ€™ll be able to update what the Assistant knows about you. Even men curious about the aging process have one question first and foremost in mind: â€œWill my penis get smaller?â€ Internet search data might be the Holy Grail when it comes to understanding the true nature of humanity. Stephens-Davidowitz, a former data scientist at Google, has spent the last four years poring over Internet search data. In addition to anonymous information about Google searches, he has â€œdownloaded all of Wikipedia, pored through Facebook profiles,â€ and even received the complete (though anonymous) search and video view data from the popular porn site PornHub. What he found is that Internet search data might be the Holy Grail when it comes to understanding the true nature of humanity. â€œI am now convinced,â€ he writes, â€œthat Google searches are the most important data set ever collected on the human psyche.â€ Here are some of his fascinating findings: SEX: Small members, big butts Google searches indicate that penis size is far more important to men than it is to women. â€œFor every search women make about a partnerâ€™s phallus,â€ Stephens-Davidowitz writes, â€œmen make roughly 170 searches about their own.â€ In addition, womenâ€™s concerns about penis size are often the opposite of what men fear, as â€œmore than 40 percent of complaints about a partnerâ€™s penis size say that itâ€™s too big.â€ The second-most common search by men, Stephens-Davidowitz found, is â€œhow to make their sexual encounters longer.â€ But here too, their concerns conflict with womenâ€™s, as â€œthere are roughly the same number of searches asking how to make a boyfriend climax more quickly as climax more slowly.â€ Of course, Google searches reveal that women too have their own body hang-ups â€” but their concerns have changed over time. In 2004, â€œthe most common search regarding changing oneâ€™s butt was how to make it smaller,â€ Stephens-Davidowitz writes. But thanks to J.Lo, Kim Kardashian and other large-bottomed beauties taking center stage, this desire did a 180 over a decade. There were more searches asking how to make your butt bigger than smaller in every state. â€œIn 2014, there were more searches asking how to make your butt bigger than smaller in every state,â€ Stephens-Davidowitz writes. â€œThese days, for every five searches looking into breast implants in the United States, there is one looking into butt implants.â€ One finding that â€œwill disturb many readers,â€ according to Stephens-Davidowitz, concerns the sort of porn women want, based on search terms typed into PornHub. â€œFully 25 percent of female searches for straight porn emphasize the pain and/or humiliation of the woman,â€ he writes, citing search terms inappropriate to reiterate here, but featuring words like â€œpainful,â€ â€œextremeâ€ and â€œbrutal,â€ and often focused on nonconsensual sex (depictions of which, he emphasizes, are not permitted on that site). â€œSearch rates for all these terms are at least twice as common among women as among men.â€ The PornHub data revealed another disconcerting fact about American sexuality â€” that we seem to be going through a disturbing incest phase. â€œA shocking number of people visiting mainstream porn sites are looking for portrayals of incest,â€ Stephens-Davidowitz writes, noting that 16 of the top 100 searches from men seek â€œincest-themed videos.â€ The number is fewer for women but still an unnerving nine out of every 100. Love and Marriage: Gay husbands and fat kids According to official surveys, married men and women each report having sex about once a week. Google, however, paints a bleak picture of American sex lives. â€œOn Google, a top complaint about a marriage is not having sex,â€ Stephens-Davidowitz writes. â€œThere are 16 times more complaints about a spouse not wanting sex than about a married partner not being willing to talk,â€ he writes. â€œSearches for â€˜sexless marriageâ€™ are three and a half times more common than â€˜unhappy marriageâ€™ and eight times more common than â€˜loveless marriage.â€™ Even unmarried couples complain somewhat frequently about not having sex. Google searches for â€˜sexless relationshipâ€™ are second only to searches for â€˜abusive relationship.â€™â€ Is my husband gay? is a surprisingly common search. These searches also show that men may be the ones holding back, as â€œthere are twice as many complaints that a boyfriend wonâ€™t have sex than that a girlfriend wonâ€™t have sex.â€ Connected or not are the findings that women often question their partnerâ€™s sexual orientation; â€œIs my husband gay?â€ is a â€œsurprisingly common search.â€ â€œâ€˜Gayâ€™ is 10 percent more likely to complete searches that begin with â€˜Is my husband . . . â€™ than the second-place word, â€˜cheating.â€™ It is eight times more common than â€˜an alcoholicâ€™ and 10 times more common than â€˜depressed.â€™â€ Google searches not only help us see another side of relationships but also help cut through the lies we tell on social media, as they starkly undermine the rosy pictures we paint on Facebook. Stephens-Davidowitz notes that the top five terms women use to describe their husbands on social media are â€œthe best,â€ â€œmy best friend,â€ â€œamazing,â€ â€œthe greatestâ€ and â€œso cute.â€ When they search anonymously, however, typing â€œmy husband is . . .â€ into a search box, the top five results are â€œgay,â€ â€œa jerk,â€ â€œamazing,â€ â€œannoyingâ€ and â€œmean.â€ And if searches reveal the depressing reality of how people feel about their mates, their attitudes toward their children are no better. When people contemplate reproducing, they worry about possible regret if they donâ€™t, as â€œpeople are seven times more likely to ask Google whether they will regret not having children than whether they will regret having children.â€ Once those kids are born, however, the sentiment undergoes a rapid reversal, as â€œadults with children are 3.6 times more likely to tell Google they regret their decision than are adults without children.â€ Google also reveals the inherit sexism among parents toward their kids. â€œParents are two and a half times more likely to ask â€˜Is my son gifted?â€™ than â€˜Is my daughter gifted?â€™â€ Stephens-Davidowitz writes, noting that this carries through for all intelligence-related queries, such as, â€œIs my son a genius?â€ (Stephens-Davidowitz notes that in reality, young girls are more likely to be in gifted programs than young boys.) Parentsâ€™ concerns for their daughters remain appearance-based, Googling â€œIs my daughter overweightâ€ twice as often as posting the same query for their sons. In reality, he notes, â€œabout 28 percent of girls are overweight, while 35 percent of boys are.â€ Racism: Shocking searches in surprising places The elections of Barack Obama in 2008 and 2012 and Donald Trump in 2016 generated much discussion about just how racist our country really is. Stephens-Davidowitz writes that Google searches help provide the answer â€” and itâ€™s not pretty. He notes that the first time he typed the N-word into Google Trends, he expected it to be â€œa low volume search.â€ â€œBoy, was I wrong,â€ he writes, noting that there were â€œmillions of these searches every year.â€ â€œIn the United States, [the N-word] was included in roughly the same number of searches as the word â€˜migraine(s),â€™ â€˜economist,â€™ and â€˜Lakers.â€™â€ Digging deeper (and eliminating the version of the word often used in hip-hop lyrics, which he thought would skew the findings), Stephens-Davidowitz found that â€œ20 percent of searches with the word . . . also include the word â€˜jokes.â€™â€ The word was also commonly paired with the phrases â€œstupid . . .â€ and â€œI hate . . .â€ Obama lost roughly 4 percentage points nationwide just from explicit racism. Examining search results from the night of Obamaâ€™s 2008 election, he found that â€œroughly one in every hundred Google searches that included the word â€˜Obamaâ€™ also included â€˜kkkâ€ or â€˜nâ€”-r(s)â€™ . . . In some states, there were more searches for â€˜nâ€”-r presidentâ€™ than â€˜first black president.â€™â€ If the sheer volume of the racism was surprising, so was its location. â€œSurveys and conventional wisdom,â€ would have us believe racism was coming more from the South than the North and more from Republicans than Democrats. Online searches, he writes, show otherwise. â€œThe places with the highest racist search rates included upstate New York, western Pennsylvania, eastern Ohio, industrial Michigan and rural Illinois, along with West Virginia, southern Louisiana and Mississippi,â€ he writes. â€œThe true divide, the data suggested, was not South versus North; it was East versus West. You donâ€™t get this sort of thing much west of the Mississippi.â€ As for party affiliation, â€œracist searches were no higher in places with a high percentage of Republicans than in places with a high percentage of Democrats.â€ This data was borne out by voting patterns. Crunching the numbers, the author estimates â€œObama lost roughly 4 percentage points nationwide just from explicit racism.â€ Share this: Facebook Twitter Google LinkedIn WhatsApp Email Copy Filed under data ,Â  google ,Â  surveillance Share this article: Share this: Facebook Twitter Google LinkedIn WhatsApp Email Copy Read Next Computer whiz curbed global cyberattack with $11 purchase Read Next Computer whiz curbed global cyberattack with $11 purchase Share Selection Trending Now on NYPost.com 41,424 Comey's firing is a gift to the FBI 34,916 Rich girl charged with shooting father after he evicted her 20,445 Dead man found on subway is fourth public corpse in four days Now On Edie Falco arrives in style to â€˜Wizard of Liesâ€™ premiere Waitress who serenaded Mariah Carey is a New Yorker Nicolas Cage was meant to star in â€˜Paris Can Waitâ€™ SEE ALL Video Here are 7 surprising things you didnâ€™t know about Howard Stern Now On The Best Erotic Thrillers on Netflix SEE ALL More Stories page six Carolina Herrera blasts Venezuela 'dictatorship' after nephew's death Now On Decider Nicole Kidman Spits Out Chef Giada De Laurentiisâ€™ Food During Contentious Cooking Segment nypost Comey's firing is a gift to the FBI New York Post Facebook Twitter Instagram LinkedIn Email Email Newsletters Mobile Apps Contact Us Tips Facebook Twitter Instagram LinkedIn Email Sections & Features News Real Estate Page Six Tech Sports Media Metro Photos Entertainment Video Business Alexa Opinion Covers Fashion Horoscopes Living Classifieds Newsletters & Feeds Email Newsletters RSS Feeds NYPost Store Home Delivery Subscribe Manage Subscription Preferences Help/Support Customer Service App FAQ & Help Contact Us Tips Newsroom Letters to the Editor Reprints Careers Apps iPhone App iPad App Android Phone Android Tablet Advertise Media Kit Contact Post Digital Network Â© 2017 NYP Holdings, Inc. Sign up now Menu ARN Update: Galaxy Nexus 4G LTE finally goes on sale Thursday Update: Galaxy Nexus 4G LTE finally goes on sale Thursday Priced at $300 on Verizon, online sales were set to start at 1 a.m. ET Thursday Computerworld Staff (Computerworld (US)) 15 December, 2011 13:02 - - - - print email Distributors ACA Pacific Alloys Australasian PC Distributors (APCD) BMS Technology Dicker Data Dynamic Supplies Impact Systems Technology Ingram Micro Australia Leader Computers Multimedia Technology Samsung Communications Synnex Topstar Computer International Wholesale IT XiT Distribution Comments The Galaxy Nexus, the first phone to run the latest version of Android, will finally go on sale Thursday from Verizon. The phone and operating system were announced in October, when Google and Samsung, which makes the phone, said it would be available in most parts of the world in November. It is already available in some countries, including Canada. Verizon has not said why it has taken longer than expected for the phone to become available. On Wednesday, it announced via Twitter that the Galaxy Nexus would go on sale the following day. Google recently pushed out a fix for a fluctuating volume issue on the phones and some people speculated that may have led to the delayed launch at Verizon. It's possible that the delay is due to a decision by Verizon to ask Google not to include Google Wallet, a new payment application, on the phones. Verizon said it made the move so it can work out technical issues. But some people have wondered if the reason is that Google Wallet could compete with Verizon's own mobile wallet initiatives. Others have suggested Verizon might be violating net neutrality rules by not allowing users to access the app. Verizon has said it continues to talk to Google about the issue. The Galaxy Nexus runs the version of Android known as Ice Cream Sandwich. It's the latest in the Nexus line of Android phones, meaning it comes stocked with all of Google's mobile applications. The operating system was designed to unite the tablet and phone versions of Android into a single release. Ice Cream Sandwich includes updates across the board, including zero shutter lag on the camera, facial recognition built into the unlock mechanism, and a new data usage management application. Nancy Gohring covers mobile phones and cloud computing for The IDG News Service. Follow Nancy on Twitter at @idgnancy . Nancy's e-mail address is Nancy_Gohring@idg.com Read more about applications in Computerworld's Applications Topic Center. solutions built for employees to customers Business Standard Google secures patent for phrase identification Google submitted that the invention was neither a mathematical algorithm nor a computer programme Gireesh BabuÂ  |Â  ChennaiÂ  May 13, 2017 Last Updated at 21:28 IST email this article Message: Recipients' Email: Type address separated by commas Your Email: Enter the characters shown in the image. Send me a copy: Â  http://mybs.in/2UViAEZ ALSO READ Nitin Pai: Dangerous times are here again United Airlines row: Know your rights, entitlements if deboarded in India GAC seeks to be first Chinese carmaker to crack United States Come on, Trump - you can't claim credit for another president's successes Google Play spend up 70%, India key contributor Internet major Google has secured a patent in India for phrase identification in an information retrieval system. Â  The system is adapted to identify phrases that have sufficient frequency and distinct use in a document collection. Good phrases are predictive of other phrases, and are not merely sequences of words that appear in the lexicon. Â  "For instance, 'President of United States' predicts other phrases such as 'George Bush' and 'Bill Clinton'. However, other phrases are not predictive, such as 'fell down the stairs', or 'top of the morning', or 'out of the blue'," Google said. Â  Phrase identification avoids having to index every possible phrase resulting from the combination of all the possible sequences of a given number of words, the company submitted to the Patent Office. Â  The Patent Office initially said the claim was simply a mathematical algorithm and was purely functional. According to the Patents Act, a mathematical or business method or a computer program is not patentable. Â  Google submitted that the invention was neither a mathematical algorithm nor a computer programme. The end product, an index stored in a memory that includes valid phrases, is inventive. Following a hearing, the deputy controller of patents and designs, Kolkata, observed, "In view of the above submissions, the technical solution i.e., the index consisting of good phrases that enables documents with related concepts to be provided in response to a query is a technical advancement over the prior art." The official added Googleâ€™s application was in order to be granted a patent. Google is having issues with account sign-in, resulting in errors with Android devices, OnHub, and Wifi Phil Oakley Follow View All Posts 2017/02/24 5:48am PDTFeb 24, 2017 18 Plus 1 on G+ 184 Share on Facebook 91 Share on Twitter Total Shares293 Google News My Google account is the key to much of what I do online, so not being able to use it is a bummer. Since yesterday, many people have been having issues signing in to their accounts - we at Android Police have been seeing this across the US and Europe. However, Google has confirmed on the Product Forums that this is not the result of a hack or malicious activity. Google is aware of the issue, and has put a note up on the Google Play support page, saying "If youâ€™ve recently been signed out of your account, sign back in using your usual username and password at https://accounts.google.com. If you canâ€™t remember your password or canâ€™t sign in for another reason, go here to recover your account password. For security reasons, our support agents are unable to assist with password issues." According to Down Detector, the company is still having issues, although possibly not as widespread as before. However, the problems are not the result of a hack or phishing, so if you have been signed out, you shouldn't need to change your password, as your account is still secure. Google account issue, having been signed out of the account. Google has confirmed that this is what has been causing Google Wifi and OnHub products to reset themselves. This unfortunately means the devices need to be set up again. Google lists how you can tell if the device has been reset, and howÂ to re-set it up, on the support page. If you've recently been signed out of your Google account, sign back in here. Let us know in the comments what you've been seeing, and we'll try and keep you updated with any new developments. Source: Google Play help, Google Wifi help, Google Product Forums, Down Detector Tags google account issues google accounts Google OnHub google wifi subscribe ... It seems that something on your end went through every request you had in that data sample (and Google's cache), invalidated tokens if it found any, then prompted the user to sign in again. Like David, I'm just speculating, as I couldn't find anything related to this in my G Suite console as well." Google's "Project Treble" will modularize Android to make updates faster Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/05/12 12:42pm PDTMay 12, 2017 95 Plus 1 on G+ 162 Share on Facebook 76 Share on Twitter Total Shares333 Android O Android OS Development Google News Easily the most annoying aspect of using an Android phone (with the exception of Pixel/Nexus) is slow updates. Android 7.1 (which came out last year) currently sits at 0.5% marketshare, and brand new phones are still being released with 6.0 Marshmallow.Â Google is aiming to solve this with "Project Treble," which will modularize part of the Android OS to decrease the time OEMs spend updating their devices. If you're not familiar with how Android updates work, here's a summary. Google releases a new Android version, which silicon manufacturers (e.g. Qualcomm, Mediatek) have to supply drivers for. Once that's done, device makers (e.g. Samsung, HTC) can start re-adding all the tweaks they have made to the new Android source code. In the case of carrier-sold phones/tablets, device makers then have to wait for the carriers to approve the update. After all that is done, users finally start to receive the update. Google is hoping to speed up this process with Project Treble, which changes the architecture of Android. Essentially, a new 'Vendor interface' will contain all of the low-level software for a device - like the chipset drivers. Google will work with chipset manufacturers to make sure the Vendor interface is forwards-compatible, and the interface will be validated by a Vendor Test Suite (VTS). The aspect of this news I'm most excited about is that the Vendor interface is forwards-compatible.Â There have been many cases where chipset manufacturers have not updated drivers for specific popular chips, preventing devices using them from being officially updated to newer Android versions. One example is the Nexus 5 and other Snapdragon 800/801-based devices, which were never officially updated to 7.0 Nougat. It sounds like the Vendor interface will prevent this from happening, or at least prolongÂ the end of support for a given chip. Google says that Android O will be the first version to use the new Vendor interface, and the Android O Developer Preview already has it. Hopefully we'll hear more about Project Treble at Google I/O next week. Source: Android Developers Tags Android android o project treble treble vendor interface vendor test suite vts subscribe ... Previous Story [Deal Alert] Finish off the week with 20 temporarily free and 4 on-sale apps ... Dorothymnelson Google is paying 97$ per hour! Its the most-financialy rewarding I've had.. PI there are quirks ,,, its not easy for highly customizable rom ,, OEM will stil rant about it and the only thing we will do rant about them ,,,and that's what we r doing for all those years,,OEM don't give a dam shadowx360 Sounds like a stopgap till they can get Fuschia running with their own kernel. Hopefully this means Google can update more core system functions similar to Google Play Services independent of the OEM/carrier path. Mike Updates still have to go through carriers, this just helps prevent devices from early EoL and should make OEMs jobs easier by not having to rewrite every piece of code to work with new drivers. TechGuy22 that's why this is useless. carriers are still involve and OEM like samsung takes time with their own skin destinyhud thats why i buy pixel. also, like mentioned this will reduce the amount of modification needed in android's new version which means slightly early release. even if its 2 weeks early i am good wit it TechGuy22 or or you can push google to make things easier for carriers and OEMs and not bandages i have an S7 edge and a pixel xl. go figure Taco Monster You can't make things easy for someone who doesn't want to do said things. bekifft It's why I buy Pixel too but the whole point of Android was supposed to be freedom and choice. If my only real choices are Google or Apple, I might as well buy a damn iPhone. PI This Daniel Not necessarily. All the OEM has to do is bring their crap (skin) from the last android version. Of course that probably only happen with small android updates (8.1?) Zsolt V Why shouldn't they? By all accounts, they add value so it's worth the wait. CA-Sandra Fuchsia is a very long term project. It's not going to replace Android anytime soon. Dextro I've been saying for ages that Android needs an hardware abstraction in the vein of what Windows has in its driver model. Hopefully this is it and helps get those updates out faster. Sadly I expect that the endless stream of UI customization OEM make will end up killing any kind of benefit this brings. Corbin Davenport I want something like that too, but I'm not deeply familiar with the technical structure of Linux/Android, so I would assume sure there some massive limitation that is keeping that from happening. Dextro I think (but am now 100% sure on this so don't quote me) that Linux historically hasn't had any such abstraction. Drivers are meant to be inside the kernel and compiled for each specific version. That works fine if the code is open source and committed to the kernel repos but it becomes a nightmare for binary blobs. The kernel makes no allowances for stable driver APIs, they will break stuff and won't worry for anything outside of the kernel if I remember correctly. That's probably part of the reason why Android has failed to keep up with Linux kernel versions. keithzg The kernel makes no allowances for stable driver APIs, they will break stuff and won't worry for anything outside of the kernel if I remember correctly. I wouldn't really say this is true. In fact, there is a very stable API provided by the Linux kernel. Hell, one of the most famous Linus rants was about this very topic: It's a bug alright - in the kernel. How long have you been a maintainer? And you *still* haven't learnt the first rule of kernel maintenance? If a change results in user programs breaking, it's a bug in the kernel. We never EVER blame the user programs. How hard can this be to understand? WE DO NOT BREAK USERSPACE! https://lkml.org/lkml/2012/12/23/75 Obviously drivers are trickier, but they're still expected to continue working. The big catch comes in that ARM drivers tend to come as compiled binary blobs. There really isn't an allowance for that in the workflow of things for Linux; good citizens are supposed to provide source, and then new kernel versions and the drivers therefore (often within the kernel itself) are recompiled, and everyone's happy. But while the API remains the same, the ABI does not; drivers compiled as modules for an older kernel won't work on newer ones, even though the drivers would almost certainly work fine if they were recompiled. The ARM space is utterly lousy with proprietary drivers (in no small part this is Qualcomm's fault, although they're far from the only offender). Hence you have Google forever backporting kernel updates to older kernels, so that the ABI remains consistent and older device drivers continue working. Dextro Well, I stand corrected then. But one question then: I was under the impression that drivers were not in userspace but in kernelspace. That's why I didn't even think much of that famous Linus rant. keithzg True, they're (generally; FUSE, for instance, is an area of exception) in kernel space, and that rant isn't entirely applicable because of that, but for practical purposes that just means ABI changes break drivers. And the kernel devs do reserve the right to change the in-kernel API at any point, which could in theory break drivers---it's just that in practice they are rather worried about such breakage and don't wish to do so, and barely break it more than they do userspace. When you think about it, it'd kindof be an insane amount of maintenance if people had to update driver code for new kernel versions! Luckily for "desktop Linux", most drivers these days in the x86 space are open source (NVIDIA is remaining holdout, although even there you can fall back to the Nouveau drivers most of the time), so they're just baked into the kernel or provided as kernel modules, and in practice don't really have to be touched by human hands after they're originally written. Unluckily for Android, that is very much not true in the ARM hardware world. Hell, most Chinese OEMs will just flatly refuse to provide kernel source, even though they're legally obligated to do so. Gaurav Kumar Which is why fuchsia has a stable ABI...like windows. I agree it's not coming anytime soon but it may not be that far away as well.. Lawstorant in the linux world, the answer is DKMS. There's no need for kernel catch-up anymore. I bet Google is doing something similar. Ð¡ÐµÑ€Ð³ÐµÐ¹ Ð‘ÑƒÐ³Ð°ÐµÐ² Android has the HAL https://source.android.com/devices/#Hardware-Abstraction-Layer -- but it haven't been helping much, as we can see (or would it be much worse without it?). It'd be interesting to see more technical details about Tremble to understand how it's different. Andy J https://developer.android.com/things/index.html pretty much this is what they are aiming for - from the days of Project Brillo. "System updates and support: We provide the system image, updates, fixes, and more, so you can focus on creating compelling products" Brillo/Things is the same idea - there is the low level vendor stuff, the actual OS and then the OEM stuff. Google can update the OS on running devices in the field, without worrying about the vendor stuff or the OEM stuff. Knowledgeborn Allah Exactly... And, unfortunately, this probably isn't going to be anything like Microsoft's new update process for Windows 10 Mobile, which doesn't have to go through carriers. Based on all the software modifications most Android OEMs make with their devices, this probably won't speed up OS updates at all. More powerful devices may last slightly longer, but that will still leave it to the OEMs to support those devices for longer periods, and they likely won't do that anyway, since they're constantly trying to get you to purchase the next one... Zsolt V Doesn't matter. The end result is the same, the user doesn't get an update. You are missing the point, maybe you don't have one? Knowledgeborn Allah Maybe I don't have one? Again, the point was based on the fact that Windows 10 Mobile updates - regardless of how many people actually have Windows 10 Mobile devices, or how many devices will be discontinued due to the Creators' update - don't have to go through carriers. That's the point. Android as a platform can learn a lot from that. The point is that you can separate core Android OS functions from the themes and launchers inherent in other variations of Android provided by other OEMs. Right now, Android's update process is a disaster. Even after the OEMs push out updates to their devices, it still has to go through various carriers to actually get to consumers, showing that the carriers are actually the ones in charge. Android has that problem. bekifft I agree completely about the HAL, but the real problem remains the network operators retaining strict control over user devices. [Update: Starts today] Google Assistant is coming to all Android 6.0 and above devices Rita El Khoury Follow View All Posts 2017/03/02 8:10am PDTMar 2, 2017 244 Plus 1 on G+ 833 Share on Facebook 222 Share on Twitter Total Shares1299 Google Marshmallow 6.0 News Nougat 7.0/7.1 Videos UpdateÂ 1: 2017/03/02 8:14am PST And right on time, it looks like the Assistant rollout to non-Pixel Android M and N devices is starting today. Google already published a short YouTube video ad and a I guess it was bound to happen: Google Assistant is finally breaking free from the shackles of the Pixels and launching onto the millions of devices running Android 6.0 Marshmallow and above, no need for GApps or root. But this shouldn't come as a surprise to you. The signs were there all along. Despite beingÂ revealed as a Pixel exclusive on phonesÂ in the Android 7.1 changelog, Assistant has been available through Allo on all Android 4.1+ phones, announced for all Android TV 6.0+ devices, and was shortly enabled by mistakeÂ throughÂ an alpha version of the Google app on non-Pixel phones. Actually, it was that same alpha app that gave us plenty of hints that Assistant would be coming to more Android devices. Plus, we've known for a while that the new LG G6 should have the Assistant, which hinted, if not confirmed, that the Pixel exclusivity was not long for this world. And nowÂ the news is official in conjunction with the launch of the LG G6. Google says the Assistant will start rolling this week to Marshmallow and Nougat devices for English users in the US followed by Australia, Canada, and the UK, plus German speakers in Germany. More languages will be added later. It willÂ replace Google Search, launching with a long press of the home button or the "OK Google" voice command. We don't know yet if it'll require an update to Play Services or if it'll be a server-side switch, but we'll sure update you either way. As for what you can do with Assistant, think of it asÂ an evolution of Google Search and "OK Google," with a bit of addedÂ functionality like smart home controls, remembering things, and an open API developers can plug into. However, don't be surprised if you notice that Assistant on your phone is still oddly missing someÂ features that Google Search has had for a while, like recognizing songs, reading messages, and adding items to specific Google Keep lists. The hope is that when Assistant launches on non-Pixels this week, it will truly replace Google Search and not lack any commands users have been issuing for years, or disappointment will ensue. The even bigger hope is thatÂ the fragmentation of what you can do with AssistantÂ on phones, Home, Wear, and Allo (not to mention TV and Auto when they are available) will no longer exist.Â Well, one can dream. UpdateÂ 1: 2017/03/02 8:14am PST And right on time, it looks like the Assistant rollout to non-Pixel Android M and N devices is starting today. Google already published a short YouTube video ad and a tweet to let everyone know this isÂ happening now. Now rolling out to more @Android phones, itâ€™s time to meet your #GoogleAssistant â†’ https://t.co/tu9bGCgo7F pic.twitter.com/aeWdgBTJH1 â€” Google (@Google) March 2, 2017 Let us know if you've started seeing Assistant on your devices andÂ check whether that involved a new Play Services version or was simply a server-side switch. Remember, the rollout is limited to English users in the US first, so you may not see it if you live overseas or if you have chosen another default language in your Google settings. End of Update Our MWC 2017 coverage is proudly sponsored by dbrand.com Source: Google Tags google assistant marshmallow mwc 2017 mwc2017 nougat pixel video subscribe ... Skip to content Naked Security Computer Security News, Advice and Research sophos.com Free Tools Go Award-winning computer security news Twitter Facebook Google+ LinkedIn Feed Memex â€“ DARPAâ€™s search engine for the Dark Web 16 Feb 2015 17 Law & order Post navigation Previous: Are Miami cops really flooding Waze with fake police sightings? Next: US wireless carriers now legally have to unlock our phones by Mark Stockley 0Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share on Google+ Share on LinkedIn Share on Reddit Anyone who used the World Wide Web in the nineties will know that web search has come a long way. Sure, it was easy to get more search results than you knew what to do with in 1999 but it was really hard to get good ones. What Google did better than Alta Vista, HotBot, Yahoo and the others at the dawn of the millennium was to figure out which search results were the most relevant and respected. And so itâ€™s been ever since â€“ search engines have become fast, simple interfaces that compete based on relevance and earn money from advertising. Meanwhile, the methods for finding things to put in the search results have remained largely the same â€“ you either tell the search engines your site exists or they find it by following a link on somebody elseâ€™s website. That business model has worked extremely well but thereâ€™s one thing that it does not excel at â€“ depth. If you donâ€™t declare your siteâ€™s existence and nobody links to it, it doesnâ€™t exist â€“ in search engine land at least. Googleâ€™s stated aim may be to organize the worldâ€™s information and make it universally accessible and useful but it hasnâ€™t succeeded yet. Thatâ€™s not just because itâ€™s difficult, itâ€™s also because Google is a business and there isnâ€™t a strong commercial imperative for it to index everything. Estimates of how much of the web has been indexed vary wildly (Iâ€™ve seen figures of 0.04% and 76% so we can perhaps narrow it down to somewhere between almost none and almost all) but one thing is sure, thereâ€™s enough stuff that hasnâ€™t been indexed that itâ€™s got itâ€™s own name â€“ the Deep Web. Itâ€™s not out of the question to suggest that the part of the web that hasnâ€™t been indexed is actually bigger than the part that has. A subset of it â€“ the part hosted on Tor Hidden Services and referred to as the Dark Web â€“ is very interesting to those in law enforcement. There are all manner of people, sites and services that operate over the web that would rather not appear in your Google search results. If youâ€™re a terrorist, paedophile, gun-runner, drug dealer, sex trafficker or serious criminal of that ilk then the shadows of the Deep Web, and particularly the Dark Web, offer a safer haven then the part occupied by, say, Naked Security or Wikipedia. Enter Memex, brainchild of the boffins at DARPA, the US government agency that built the internet (then ARPANET). DARPA describes Memex as a set of search tools that are better suited to government (presumably law enforcement and intelligence) use than commercial search engines. Whereas Google and Bing are designed to be good-enough systems that work for everyone, Memex will end up powering domain-specific searches that are the very best solution for specific narrow interests (such as certain types of crime.) Today's web searches use a centralized, one-size-fits-all approach that searches the internet with the same set of tools for all queries. While that model has been wildly successful commercially, it does not work well for many government use cases. The goal is for users to ... quickly and thoroughly organize subsets of information based on individual interests ... and to improve the ability of military, government and commercial enterprises to find and organize mission-critical publically [sic] available information on the internet. Although Memex will eventually have a very broad range of applications, the projectâ€™s initial focus is on tackling human trafficking and slavery. According to DARPA, human trafficking has a significant Dark Web presence in the form of forums, advertisements, job postings and hidden services (anonymous sites available via Tor). Memex has been available to a few law enforcement agencies for about a year and has already been used with some success. In September 2014, sex trafficker Benjamin Gaston was sentenced to a minimum of 50 years in prison having been found guilty of â€œSex Trafficking, as well as Kidnapping, Criminal Sexual Act, Rape, Assault, and Sex Abuse â€“ all in the First Degreeâ€. Scientific American reports that Memex was in the thick of it: A key weapon in the prosecutor's arsenal, according to the NYDA's Office: an experimental set of internet search tools the US Department of Defense is developing to help catch and lock up human traffickers. The journal also reports that Memex is used by the New York County District Attorneyâ€™s Office in every case pursued by its Human Trafficking Response Unit, and it has playedÂ a role in generating at least 20 active sex trafficking investigations. If Memex carries on like this then weâ€™ll have to think of a new name for the Dark Web. He is also a writer for Sophos, is the founder of independent web consultancy Compound Eye and he's interested in literally anything that makes websites better. Follow him on Twitter at <a href="https://twitter.com/MarkStockley">@MarkStockley</a> 17 comments on â€œMemex â€“ DARPAâ€™s search engine for the Dark Webâ€ Dysentery says: February 16, 2015 at 7:34 pm Political dissenters will have to find another planet pretty soon Reply Mark Stockley says: February 16, 2015 at 11:07 pm This system is not designed to identify anonymous users or to uncover the true location of things hidden by hidden services (the â€˜hiddenâ€™ bit of hidden services is their virtual location, not their content.) Itâ€™s designed to find things that are dark because the current generation of search engines canâ€™t or wonâ€™t find them, not because theyâ€™re encrypted. So, using your example, a dissenter who publishes dissent using a Tor hidden service and takes steps to avoid identifying themselves in the words they write would not be identified as a specific individual and their siteâ€™s location wouldnâ€™t be revealed but the fact that their site exists might be. So if youâ€™re trying to get word out, it might be a good thing. The Dark Web is dark for the same reason that lots of the countryside is â€“ itâ€™s just not worth the cost of putting up street lights. Reply Joe says: May 20, 2016 at 1:55 am Interstate 60 comes to mind. :) TBH, most of the so-called dark web is not even technically â€˜WWWâ€™ AKA http/https traffic. Itâ€™s stuff like IRC and FTP (old school!) and P2P filesharing and even yes, anti-spying (privacy) networks. Of course, TOR and Freenet are forms of P2P but not intended primarily for sharing files. Reply Brad Mathers says: February 18, 2015 at 6:12 pm Somebody needs to check what Memex means in Bahasa, Indonesia, just saying Reply 4caster says: February 21, 2015 at 10:57 pm There is no such word in bahasa Indonesia, which has no letter x. How stupid do you think people are? Do you think theyâ€™ll not figure it out? Get a clue. Nice job, Mark! Reply andrewfnam says: February 18, 2015 at 8:08 pm Thanks Mark for the great summary makes a lot of sense. Reply Laurence Marks says: February 25, 2015 at 2:05 am Mark wrote â€œMeanwhile, the methods for finding things to put in the search results have remained largely the same â€“ you either tell the search engines your site exists or they find it by following a link on somebody elseâ€™s website.â€ I thought that they simply tried to open port 80 iterating over IP addresses 0.0.0.1, 0.0.0.2, â€¦,126.255.255.254, 126.255.255.255, 128.0.0.1, 128.0.0.2,â€¦,255.255.255.253,255.255.255.254. Thatâ€™s what they would have had to do in the first place anyway. And itâ€™s the easiest refresh scheme for providers like Yahoo! and Google. Reply Mark Stockley says: February 25, 2015 at 2:18 pm The industry uses name-based virtual hosting extensively so any given IP address could harbour any number of websites, none of which will be accessible with the IP alone (and you need to supply a hostname for a valid HTTP 1.1 request anyway.) So you need to get a list of hostnames from somewhere and you canâ€™t get them by reverse DNS on the IP. The search engines use spidering â€“ they follow links or you give them a sitemap. This works on the regular World Wide Web because people want to have their sites indexed so Google and Bing donâ€™t have to try hard to find them. Reply Anonymous says: July 6, 2015 at 9:57 pm How does one log into Memex in order to use it as a search engine? Do I enter it in IEâ€™s search engine screen? Reply William says: November 28, 2015 at 2:05 am Does Memex index websites in a manner that ignores robots.txt rules. If so, is there any liability if such indexing causes damage to a Web server, accidentally or otherwise? Reply P Tegler says: March 4, 2016 at 5:07 pm there are no â€˜lawsâ€™ saying spider MUST obey robot files. Itâ€™s a courtesy and a way for engines to stop themselves from being black listed. (which you can do easliy in your config files) Reply mike says: February 27, 2016 at 8:00 pm TheÂ memexÂ (a portmanteau of â€œmemoryâ€ and â€œindexâ€) is the name of the hypothetical proto-hypertext system that Vannevar Bush described in his 1945 The Atlantic Monthly article â€œAs We May Thinkâ€. And the company takes its plans a step further by acquiring Owlchemy Labs, a VR studio mostly known for Job Simulator and Rick and Morty: Virtual Rick-ality. But, why Google chose Owlchemy Labs Owlchemy co-founder Alex Schwartz said that the studio will continue to work on VR games, but now they have Googleâ€™s support. â€œWe have a slate of original games that we have in [the] production and prototyping phase, and weâ€™re going to continue to do that,â€ â€œWeâ€™re very excited to continue to do that with the support of Google behind us.â€ Also on a blog post Owlchemy reveals that their goal is â€œcontinuing to focus on hand interactions and high quality user experiences, like with Job Simulator.â€ And Schwartz adds that full-motion hand tracking is â€œkind of our key factor.â€ And for the record Owlchemy Labs didnâ€™t always handled virtual reality games. In 2011 they released the infamous game Smuggle Truck. The studio gained reputation when it became one of the first studios to work with the first Oculus Rift development kit in 2013. Of course the release of Job Simulator was one the titles for PlayStation VR, HTC Vive, and Oculus Touch motion controllers. Its success was pretty big and the title managed to gather $3 million in sales at the beginning of 2017. Now, Google hasnâ€™t announced any immediate plans about virtual reality but many reports suggest that at Googleâ€™s I/O developer conference next week, the company might shares a few news. Now, if you donâ€™t know much about the famous game Job Simulator, keep reading for some info. In this game players participate in simulated jobs in a job museum run by robots resembling floating CRT. The jobs are represented as tongue-in-cheek approximations of real occupations: â€œAuto Mechanicâ€, â€œGourmet Chefâ€, â€œStore Clerkâ€ and â€œOffice Workerâ€. Accompanied by a computer character who provides exposition and instructions, players perform tasks associated with that occupation, some realistic and others more funny. For example, in the â€œOffice Workerâ€ simulation, players participate in activities like evaluating new employees and transferring calls, but are also called upon to eat doughnuts, share photos at the water cooler. Of course the fun part is the use of the motion controllers of the HTC Vive to represent their hands. Users interact with the virtual environment similarly to how they would in real life. And when the player completes all four job simulations, the have the chance to modify the physics of the gameplay. So, whatâ€™s the studio next plans and how Google is going to work with them? Google Maps Local Guides cuts Level 4 free Drive storage from 1TB to 100GB Rita El Khoury Follow View All Posts 2016/07/07 4:27am PDTJul 7, 2016 135 Plus 1 on G+ 110 Share on Facebook 1 Share on Twitter Total Shares246 Google News Back in November of 2015, Google expanded its Local Guides program with a points and level system that introduced new rewards for each tier. At 200 points, you would reach the coveted Level 4 and receive 1TB of free Google Drive storage for 2 years. Now Google is backing away from that promise and lowering the amount of free storage to 100GB only. It might be that Google Maps' recent updates that incentivize you with notifications to post photos, reviews, and answer questions about places you're visiting have had a positive effect and Google is seeing more and more people reach Level 4. This is why, in order to provide everyone with free storage, it's lowering the amount to 100GB instead of 1TB. At least that's the reason given toÂ Local Guides in a new email that's going out to them: As the corresponding Local Guides support document states, those who are already signed up to the program have until July 21 2016 to reach Level 4 and redeem their freeÂ 1TB Drive storage. After that date, or for those who aren't Local Guides yet, the free storage will go down to 100GB. Excuse me while I scramble to post all the photos and reviews that I've been putting off for months... and try to understand why of my 97 (mostly detailed) reviews, Local Guides is only counting 12. What the hell, Google?! Source: Local Guides support Tags free google drive storage google maps Level 4 local guide local guides subscribe ... Lynxy It's also very easy if a certain chain of whatever (coffee shops, gas stations etc) doesn't have listed opening hours yet. Just go from chain location to location and add their hours (they're probably listed for all chain locations on their website). Trent Archer I've found the easiest way to get points is edits to incorrect place names. I initially went with photos as so many places (especially in smaller towns) don't have a decent picture up, or any picture at all. Then I realised just how many places have names stuffed with keywords. For example, Costa Coffee Liverpool should actually just be called Costa, classified as a coffee shop and located in Liverpool. Wells Fargo Bank should just be Wells Fargo. A lot of people mistakenly think they're helping by putting keywords relevant to the business into its name and business owners think there's an advantage in it. In reality, it just leads to a less efficient, clean and tidy map. benoita74 Excellent tip thank you, got me a 100 points in 20 minutes ;) Stevie_Wonder Thanks! This worked for me too, got 150 points or something like that in an hour. And just got my 1TB Drive space. If it existed I voted for you for AndroidPolice commenter of the month! Better to claim the higher storage limit now and not need it than to get it down the road and turn out to be desperate for more. benoita74 But then what's the use of having it for only two years ? Sign up now Menu ARN Facebook, Google, Twitter sued by father of Paris terror victim Facebook, Google, Twitter sued by father of Paris terror victim Reynaldo Gonzalez charges the companies with letting their forums be used as tools of the Islamic State group John Ribeiro (IDG News Service) 16 June, 2016 16:16 - - - - print email Distributors Synnex Comments The use of social networks like Facebook, Twitter and Googleâ€™s YouTube by terrorist groups for propaganda, recruitment, fundraising and other activities has come into sharp focus recently. It seemed inevitable that these companies would at some point be blamed for the misuse of these forums and become targets of lawsuits from families of victims. A lawsuit filed in a federal court in California by the father of Nohemi Gonzalez, a victim of the Paris terror attack in November, charges that Twitter, Facebook and Google â€œhave knowingly permitted the terrorist group ISIS [Islamic State group] to use their social networks as a tool for spreading extremist propaganda, raising funds and attracting new recruits.â€ Gonzalez, a U.S. citizen, was killed in November when militants sprayed bullets into the bistro at which she was dining with friends. A similar suit has been brought against Twitter in January by the widow of a person killed in Jordan. In that lawsuit as also the lawsuit filed by Nohemi's father, Reynaldo Gonzalez, the companies are likely to invoke Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, which states that "no provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider." That provision protects online intermediaries from being held responsible for content hosted on their websites by third parties, which in this case would include the ISIS. Congress has "broadly immunized entities like Twitter against lawsuits that seek to hold them liable for harmful or unlawful third-party content, including suits alleging that such entities failed to block, remove, or alter such content," Twitter said in its defense in the January lawsuit. The January complaint does not allege any direct connection between Twitter and the killer Anwar Abu Zaid or the attack on the police compound in Jordan that killed Lloyd Fields, the victim in the attack, Twitter said. "Nor does it allege that Twitter itself created any of the Tweets, messages, or other content that the Complaint strains to link, even indirectly, to that attack," it added. The Gonzalez complaint alleges that the three companies provided material support to terrorists under 18 U.S. Code 2339A and 2339B. â€œThe services and support that Defendants purposefully, knowingly or with willful blindness provided to ISIS constitute material support to the preparation and carrying out of acts of international terrorism, including the attack in which Nohemi Gonzalez was killed,â€ according to the complaint filed Tuesday. The complaint cites numerous instances of the misuse of the networks by the ISIS and also points to the revenue earned by the companies by placing advertisements on posts by the terrorists groups. â€œAstonishingly, Defendants routinely profit from ISIS. Each Defendant places ads on ISIS postings and derives revenue for the ad placement,â€ according to the filing. Social networks for their part claim they are doing their best to weed out terrorist content though it is turning out to be like trying to whack-a-mole, with the proscribed content or new content resurfacing elsewhere. YouTube has a strong track record of taking swift action against terrorist content, said a Google spokesman, who said the company would not comment on pending litigation. â€œWe have clear policies prohibiting terrorist recruitment and content intending to incite violence and quickly remove videos violating these policies when flagged by our users. We also terminate accounts run by terrorist organizations or those that repeatedly violate our policies," he wrote in an email. A Facebook spokeswoman wrote that â€œthere is no place for terrorists or content that promotes or supports terrorism on Facebook, and we work aggressively to remove such content as soon as we become aware of it." A Twitter spokesman said â€œviolent threats and the promotion of terrorism deserve no place on Twitter and, like other social networks, our rules make that clear.â€ In a post on combating violent extremism in February, Twitter said that as noted by many experts and other companies, â€œthere is no â€˜magic algorithmâ€™ for identifying terrorist content on the internet, so global online platforms are forced to make challenging judgment calls based on very limited information and guidance.â€ Gonzalez is asking the court for compensatory damages to be decided in a trial. The lawsuit is likely to add to other pressures the social networking companies are already facing on the terror issue from various quarters including Congress. Senators Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat from California, and Richard Burr, a Republican from North Carolina, for example, proposed legislation in December that would require tech companies to report online terrorist activity to law enforcement. Google's "Project Treble" will modularize Android to make updates faster Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/05/12 12:42pm PDTMay 12, 2017 95 Plus 1 on G+ 162 Share on Facebook 76 Share on Twitter Total Shares333 Android O Android OS Development Google News Easily the most annoying aspect of using an Android phone (with the exception of Pixel/Nexus) is slow updates. Android 7.1 (which came out last year) currently sits at 0.5% marketshare, and brand new phones are still being released with 6.0 Marshmallow.Â Google is aiming to solve this with "Project Treble," which will modularize part of the Android OS to decrease the time OEMs spend updating their devices. If you're not familiar with how Android updates work, here's a summary. Google releases a new Android version, which silicon manufacturers (e.g. Qualcomm, Mediatek) have to supply drivers for. Once that's done, device makers (e.g. Samsung, HTC) can start re-adding all the tweaks they have made to the new Android source code. In the case of carrier-sold phones/tablets, device makers then have to wait for the carriers to approve the update. After all that is done, users finally start to receive the update. Google is hoping to speed up this process with Project Treble, which changes the architecture of Android. Essentially, a new 'Vendor interface' will contain all of the low-level software for a device - like the chipset drivers. Google will work with chipset manufacturers to make sure the Vendor interface is forwards-compatible, and the interface will be validated by a Vendor Test Suite (VTS). The aspect of this news I'm most excited about is that the Vendor interface is forwards-compatible.Â There have been many cases where chipset manufacturers have not updated drivers for specific popular chips, preventing devices using them from being officially updated to newer Android versions. One example is the Nexus 5 and other Snapdragon 800/801-based devices, which were never officially updated to 7.0 Nougat. It sounds like the Vendor interface will prevent this from happening, or at least prolongÂ the end of support for a given chip. Google says that Android O will be the first version to use the new Vendor interface, and the Android O Developer Preview already has it. Hopefully we'll hear more about Project Treble at Google I/O next week. Source: Android Developers Tags Android android o project treble treble vendor interface vendor test suite vts subscribe ... Of course that probably only happen with small android updates (8.1?) Zsolt V Why shouldn't they? By all accounts, they add value so it's worth the wait. CA-Sandra Fuchsia is a very long term project. It's not going to replace Android anytime soon. Dextro I've been saying for ages that Android needs an hardware abstraction in the vein of what Windows has in its driver model. Hopefully this is it and helps get those updates out faster. Sadly I expect that the endless stream of UI customization OEM make will end up killing any kind of benefit this brings. Corbin Davenport I want something like that too, but I'm not deeply familiar with the technical structure of Linux/Android, so I would assume sure there some massive limitation that is keeping that from happening. Dextro I think (but am now 100% sure on this so don't quote me) that Linux historically hasn't had any such abstraction. Drivers are meant to be inside the kernel and compiled for each specific version. That works fine if the code is open source and committed to the kernel repos but it becomes a nightmare for binary blobs. The kernel makes no allowances for stable driver APIs, they will break stuff and won't worry for anything outside of the kernel if I remember correctly. That's probably part of the reason why Android has failed to keep up with Linux kernel versions. keithzg The kernel makes no allowances for stable driver APIs, they will break stuff and won't worry for anything outside of the kernel if I remember correctly. I wouldn't really say this is true. In fact, there is a very stable API provided by the Linux kernel. Hell, one of the most famous Linus rants was about this very topic: It's a bug alright - in the kernel. How long have you been a maintainer? And you *still* haven't learnt the first rule of kernel maintenance? If a change results in user programs breaking, it's a bug in the kernel. We never EVER blame the user programs. How hard can this be to understand? WE DO NOT BREAK USERSPACE! https://lkml.org/lkml/2012/12/23/75 Obviously drivers are trickier, but they're still expected to continue working. The big catch comes in that ARM drivers tend to come as compiled binary blobs. There really isn't an allowance for that in the workflow of things for Linux; good citizens are supposed to provide source, and then new kernel versions and the drivers therefore (often within the kernel itself) are recompiled, and everyone's happy. But while the API remains the same, the ABI does not; drivers compiled as modules for an older kernel won't work on newer ones, even though the drivers would almost certainly work fine if they were recompiled. The ARM space is utterly lousy with proprietary drivers (in no small part this is Qualcomm's fault, although they're far from the only offender). Hence you have Google forever backporting kernel updates to older kernels, so that the ABI remains consistent and older device drivers continue working. Dextro Well, I stand corrected then. But one question then: I was under the impression that drivers were not in userspace but in kernelspace. That's why I didn't even think much of that famous Linus rant. keithzg True, they're (generally; FUSE, for instance, is an area of exception) in kernel space, and that rant isn't entirely applicable because of that, but for practical purposes that just means ABI changes break drivers. And the kernel devs do reserve the right to change the in-kernel API at any point, which could in theory break drivers---it's just that in practice they are rather worried about such breakage and don't wish to do so, and barely break it more than they do userspace. When you think about it, it'd kindof be an insane amount of maintenance if people had to update driver code for new kernel versions! Luckily for "desktop Linux", most drivers these days in the x86 space are open source (NVIDIA is remaining holdout, although even there you can fall back to the Nouveau drivers most of the time), so they're just baked into the kernel or provided as kernel modules, and in practice don't really have to be touched by human hands after they're originally written. Unluckily for Android, that is very much not true in the ARM hardware world. Hell, most Chinese OEMs will just flatly refuse to provide kernel source, even though they're legally obligated to do so. Gaurav Kumar Which is why fuchsia has a stable ABI...like windows. I agree it's not coming anytime soon but it may not be that far away as well.. Lawstorant in the linux world, the answer is DKMS. There's no need for kernel catch-up anymore. I bet Google is doing something similar. Andy J https://developer.android.com/things/index.html pretty much this is what they are aiming for - from the days of Project Brillo. Google can update the OS on running devices in the field, without worrying about the vendor stuff or the OEM stuff. Knowledgeborn Allah Exactly... Also if those Vendor APIs will have limits to certain OS aspects like camera, sound etc., then manufacturers will not use them and will just fork again the OS as done currently. saf1927 The custom ROMs that work on Nexus 5 devices don't actually benefit from a lot of things that an officially supported device would. Qualcomm has completely abandoned the chip so from a retail perspective, it's not suitable anymore. Even the "security updates" that these ROMs show in "About phone" aren't actually all implemented, since none of the proprietary blobs and binaries could be updated. Just because a device can be updated with a custom ROM, doesn't mean it's actually running it well. someone755 "Just because it's running it well doesn't mean it's running it well." Welp. saf1927 Wait, what? I can't find that sentence anywhere and I don't remember editing the comment. AbdulB1 Mediatek and in some casesâ€‹ Qualcomm (for Nexus 5,sd800,801) don't want people to stay on old phones they try to force them to buy new phones for latest Android version. I am not sure will they be happy about this change? I suspect they will flood market with phones running Android nougat instead. They will try to resist this change by Google. saf1927 Mediatek and Qualcomm aren't device makers, they are silicon manufacturers. AbdulB1 Mediatek charges device makers for new drivers for latest Android versions. Qualcomm stopped supporting sd 800/801 for Android Nougat and thus even sony a device maker who was developing Android N developer versions for a SD800/801 stopped. Chipset makers also have huge clout , it not just sensor makers who decide to support or not their older hardware for newer Android release. saf1927 Well, my point is that none of the silicon manufacturers will force anyone to make only Nougat phones, like you claimed. AbdulB1 "Google will work with chipset manufacturers to make sure the Vendor interface is forwards-compatible, and the interface will be validated by a Vendor Test Suite (VTS)." so if Vendor dont get validated for VTS then do you expect any chances of Android O for those devices? dizel123 I suspect if OEMs want to release new phones with the latest OS version because that's what their users want(I know I'm making assumptions) and Mediatek and Qualcomm try to force them to release phones with Nougat, then Intel will suddenly become a dominant player in the mobile market. This would be exactly the kind of "in" they're praying for. AbdulB1 Intel architecture is quite old , I owned 2 Intel based Android tablets. Intel even didn't bothered to upgrade the OS from 4.0.4 and other one had 5.0 as latest release even it though it was buggy as hell and every hardware vendor went for 5.1 instead. Intel had an edge of running windows along android on their cpu tech. But lack of proper built in modem destroyed their chances in Android world. Their SOCs still had quite high consumption even after releasing newer and newer generations of Mobile SOCs. dizel123 I don't have any inside information, but I'm guessing Intel is working on fixing their problems and making high quality SOCs Cakefish Intel dropped out of the mobile SOC wars. For example, Sony and Qualcomm contributed dozens of features and hundreds of bugfixes to Android O so they no longer need to rework these patches with each new release of Android."
